The project has a consultative committee of 14 members made up of representatives of accounting and legal firms, the Australian Society of Chartered Practising Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Corporate Tax Association, the National Farmers Federation and the Taxation Institute of Australia. Also, there are two private sector representatives.

The announcement followed a recommendation by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts made in November 1993 that the government establish a broadly based task force to redraft the principal act. The project has also released a broad framework. It makes clear that the project is not about reforming the tax system or reviewing tax policy. It will focus on administrative rules that are overly complex, unnecessary or out of date with today's reality. However, the framework made clear that:

SPEECH.PARA: When redrafting, the project team may come across provisions where the meaning is unclear. Those cases may require the Government to clarify the policy, so the law can be more clearly written.

The new rules are designed to be shorter, clearer, simpler and more readable than is the present law. This is to be achieved by restructuring, renumbering and rewriting the legislation as has already been indicated.

PARA.TAB: The aim is to reduce compliance costs by rewriting the principal act and other tax laws so that it is easier to understand—an aim, I am afraid to say, on this first example which will only be partially successful. At the current pace at which the project team is working, the objectives cannot be met until early next century, although I personally would hope that there is some improvement on that possible timetable. The project team has indicated that it is also looking at depreciation, research and development, and primary production losses.

The major shortcoming with this whole exercise has been the narrowness of the review. Complex tax policy issues which need to be addressed to achieve any major simplification of the tax system have been totally ignored in this bill with the emphasis of this project resting 100 per cent on using plain English and adopting a simple legislative structure. This is to be commended but, as I will go on to outline, it goes nowhere near far enough.

The bill provides that the new substantiation provisions will apply to expenses incurred on or after 1 July 1994. This contrasts with the exposure draft which provided for a 1 July 1995 starting date. The existing law will apply only to expenses incurred before 1 July 1994, obviously. However, a special provision is included so that in the 1994-95 income year, if the new law would deny a deduction allowable under the existing law or allow a lesser deduction than under the existing law, a taxpayer can nevertheless claim the amount allowable under the old law.

The substantiation provisions affect seven out of 10 taxpayers. The number of people estimated to be affected is 5.4 million taxpayers. As the Assistant Treasurer pointed out, the financial impact of this bill will be minimal. Most of the administrative changes will have no impact on the revenue, with the exception of the removal of car expenses from the $300 substantiation threshold exemption, which will cost up to $10 million per annum, I understand.

Most measures should reduce compliance costs but there will be some increase in compliance costs for individual business persons who undertake short-term domestic travel over a period of one to five nights inclusive. Presently, they are not required to maintain any records but the bill requires that they obtain written evidence. Also the compliance costs to salary and wage earners will increase for those who must now retain records for five years instead of 3 1/2 years and they will be disadvantaged and incur additional costs, presumably.

The main substantive changes proposed to make the substantiation rules less cumbersome are as follows: for car expenses, logbook rules are now less complex or will be under this legislation. This development is welcome, although the complex requirement to maintain a logbook remains the same. Taxpayers can base their business use percentage on a reasonable estimate of the number of kilometres the car travels during the year in the course of producing assessable income. But taxpayers must keep a new logbook for a stipulated period every five years to establish the basis of allowable expenditure in subsequent years. This reduces the number of situations in which a new logbook must be kept and that is to taxpayers' advantage.

Car expenses will now be calculated by the cents per kilometre method. The application of this method of calculating car expense deductions will be extended so that taxpayers who travel more than 5,000 business kilometres may claim for 5,000 kilometres. However, car expenses will now be exempt from the scope of the $300 substantiation-free concession. This change has occurred because in the past, when car expenses were significant, the $300 limit was easily exceeded, with the result that both work and car expenses had to be substantiated.

The substantiation requirements for travel expenses are to be standardised by removing the need for taxpayers to keep a diary for short-term overseas travel and requiring business taxpayers to get written evidence of expenses incurred during short-term domestic travel. In future, taxpayers will be able to claim up to $150 for deductible laundry expenses without providing receipts. Existing law requires taxpayers to substantiate all laundry expenses, and we know what a nonsense that proved to be.

The bill requires taxpayers to keep records for five years. This will reduce the period which business taxpayers must keep records by a period of two years, but increase it for salary and wage earners by some 18 months. This change will, no doubt, require taxpayers to take greater care in keeping records. I hope and trust they become aware of that obligation and the extended period for which they must maintain those records. Taxpayers, generally, are not good at record maintenance procedures and are more likely to either misplace, lose or unintentionally dispose of the required substantiation receipts within a period of five years or even less.

Under the new rules, taxpayers are required to obtain written evidence for allowable expenditure in three different categories. The first of these is for work expenses. The second is for domestic and overseas business travel expenses for which a travel diary must be kept if a person is away from his or her ordinary residence for six or more nights in a row. Similarly, the third category is for car expenses other than fuel and oil expenses if the taxpayer uses the one-third of actual expenses method or the logbook method to calculate car expenses. Odometer records must be kept for car expenses if the one-third of actual expenses method is used, the expenses are for fuel and oil, and the taxpayer does not get written evidence of it.

Substantiation is not now required for some six or seven categories of allowable expenditure. The first is work expenses of $300 or less, including laundry expenses, but not travel or meal allowance expenses or expenses covered by an award transport payment. The second category that does not require substantiation, as has already been mentioned, is laundry expenses of $150 or less. The third category not requiring substantiation involves expenses on motor vehicles that are not cars—for example, a motorcycle—or are not owned or leased—for example, a borrowed car—unless it is a taxi fare or similar expense or an expense incurred in travel outside Australia.

Substantiation in the fourth category covers expenses by an award transport payment—that is, transport payment covering travel paid under an industrial instrument in force at 29 October 1986—if the taxpayer claims less than the amount payable on 29 October 1986. The fifth category includes overtime meal allowance expenses covered by an allowance payable under an Australian law. If the commissioner considers the amount the taxpayer claims to be reasonable, the expense will not have to be substantiated.

The sixth category is expenses covered by travel allowance. If the commissioner considers the amount the taxpayer claims is reasonable, having regard to expenses it would be reasonable to incur for travel within Australia, the expenses will not have to be substantiated on accommodation, food, drink or incidental travel expenses or, if overseas, on food, drink or incidental travel expenses. In that case, taxpayers must still keep travel records. Travel records, however, are not needed for travel allowance expenses covered by, and not more than, a travel allowance for travel principally overseas if the expenses are incurred by an aircraft crew member.

The following written evidence will be required for depreciation expenses. Taxpayers must obtain written evidence in the form of a document from the supplier of the property which sets out the name of the supplier, the cost of the property to the taxpayer, the nature of the property, the day the taxpayer acquired the property and the date of the document. Written evidence for expenses other than depreciation must be obtained from the supplier of the goods or services setting out the name of the supplier, the amount of the expense in the currency incurred, the nature of the goods or services, the day the expense was incurred and the date of the document. If a document from a supplier does not show the nature of the property, goods or services, then the taxpayers can add that information themselves. If the supplier's document does not show the day the expense was incurred, then a taxpayer can use a bank statement or other reasonable independent evidence to show that it was paid.

It is rather onerous on the part of the Australian Taxation Office to expect taxpayers, every time they purchase goods and services, to check that the receipt they have obtained contains all the required information. If the receipt is lacking the required information, the taxpayer will have to fill in the missing gaps before lodging a tax return. This occurs in an environment where no supplier of goods and services is legally compelled under any state or federal law to actually provide an original receipt, invoice or statement in such a format.

Almost every receipt received by a taxpayer would fail to record the statutory requirements now to be imposed by those provisions. A taxpayer can make his or her own record of expenses instead of getting a document from a supplier if each expense to be deducted is $10 or less, all of them total $200 or less, or the commissioner considers it unreasonable to expect a taxpayer to get a document from the supplier.

The taxpayer should, however, record in a diary, or similar document, details of activities undertaken during travel in the course of producing assessable income. If this is not done, the activities cannot be taken into account in apportioning travel expenses. The details in such a case to be recorded are: the nature of the travel activity, the day and approximate time it began, how long it lasted and where the taxpayer engaged in it.

A complete copy can substitute for original documents which are lost or destroyed. If the commissioner is satisfied that the taxpayer took reasonable precautions to prevent the loss or destruction, the deduction is not affected if the document was not written evidence. If the document was written evidence, the taxpayer must try to get a substitute document with the same information. If it is not reasonably possible to do that, then the deduction is not affected.

With this bill the government has missed the opportunity to simplify complex tax policy, which is what taxpayers and businesses really need. Those examples of requirements still in force illustrate that point. The tax law improvement project is only about using plain English and a simpler and easier to follow legislative structure—nothing more, nothing less. Most of the changes in the current substantiation requirements are not significant enough. While they are important, such as the removal of requirements, including the signing of every entry in a logbook and keeping records for laundry expenses, the process must go further. Having a look at the clock, it might suit the convenience of the House if I interrupted my remarks again.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —We in this House pay tribute from time to time to past members and also to the work of outstanding Australians. It gives me great pleasure tonight to pay tribute in that same way to a person whom I can only describe as being one of the finest Australians, but a person most members of this House would not know. As he believed in and respected the institution of parliament—although he did not always agree with it—I believe it is a worthy tribute.

PARA.TAB: Henry Darwen died on 21 October 1994. On that day Australia lost a fine Australian. At the same time, the town of Bowen in North Queensland lost probably one of its most dedicated sons and citizens. There are few people to whom one can attribute as many positive initiatives in their lives as one can to Henry Darwen in his 81 years. He was born in 1913 and in his 81 years not only served his country and community but was a great example for what he contributed to his family and community. Few have been respected in the way he was. He used his 81 years to advance his community, to defend his country in war and also to defend Bowen in peace.

He was born in Bowen and his father was the editor and publisher of the local paper and was mayor for a term of three years. I believe this set a pattern for the contribution he was later to make. He went into the publishing business at the Bowen Independent very early in 1929 and served on that paper until it was sold to a conglomerate in 1985. He took great pride in the fact that, at the time of the sale, the Bowen Independent was one of the only two purely family independent papers in Queensland. As a publisher, he used his efforts at all times to promote the community and the development in Bowen, his home town.

Bowen people are very restrictive in their views of history. They believe that Bowen instead of Townsville should have been the port for Mount Isa. There is also the age factor. Bowen was one of the first communities settled in North Queensland—if not the first—and is positioned on one of the great natural harbours. Despite that, Townsville won the contract to be the outlet for Mount Isa. Notwithstanding that, Henry Darwen did everything he could to promote Bowen. In the time of Dr Peter Delamothe's membership of the state parliament, Mr Darwen assisted him in all ways that would give further recognition to Bowen. He served on the local council as the deputy mayor and was always prepared to jump in and do the things that were required.

In this year where Australia remembers its activities during the Second World War, it is fitting to comment that he served his country. He joined the CMF as a member of the Bowen Detachment in 1936; was active in service between 1941 and 1945; and served in Cape York, Dutch New Guinea and Northern New Guinea and was discharged as a sergeant. In both peace and war, in all of his activities he was able to maintain a sense of direction with his family and within the community.

He was a member of the Anglican Church and assisted it in every way he could. He was also the chairman of the Bowen Harbour Board, with the firm belief still that Bowen should have been the port for North Queensland instead of Townsville, and he did everything he could to further that view. He was awarded an OBE in 1975 for his achievements in public life of remarkable standard and diversity.

It is sad to know that Henry Darwen in life is no more. But he lives on because so many of us are happy and privileged to have known him and to be able to claim a friendship with him both in business and personally, which is a fine thing to be able to say. To Mary, his wife, I would like to say that Mavis, my wife, and I admire and recognise her role and contribution to the partnership and marriage. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Road Transport Authority New South Wales Bike Ride

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to herald an event which will take place within my electorate at Bundanoon on 4 March. I refer to the RTA New South Wales bike ride. I congratulate all those involved for the work that has been done over the last two years to bring this event to my electorate.

PARA.TAB: It is with some degree of pride that I stand here and take some of the credit for this, having been the person who initiated the whole program so those in my electorate could go out as a community and put a bid to the New South Wales Bicycle Institute to hold the bike ride. There was a degree of cynicism and scepticism about my motives. They evaporated once we won the bid and the realisation came that somewhere in the order of $700,000 to stage the event would be focused on my electorate and that it was estimated that towns along the route would earn in the vicinity of $30,000 a night when the participants went through those villages and townships. This has not happened all by itself. I feel privileged to be part of the leadership team which has put this together for the benefit of the people in our area.

This event is not a one-off occurrence from their federal member. It has been followed up by a very successful seminar with the small business people and tourism operators in my electorate to discuss green jobs and the delivery of green jobs subsequent to a number of environmental decisions which were favourable to my electorate. That seminar—which was attended by Trish Caswell, the President of the ACF, and the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee)—gave some heartened direction towards our bid to provide tourism as a vehicle for obtaining jobs and for capturing income which was generated outside our region.

Mr Speaker, being a fellow member of IREDO, you would be aware that our approach has been to take a regional focus. I have had discussions today with certain people within the tourist industry in my electorate who are looking to make this New South Wales RTA bike ride a showcase for my electorate—the beginning of a package of approaches to market our area for the year 2000 games.

Many people claim that politicians indulge in rhetoric and little else. I ask the House to acknowledge that, if we sustain our effort towards a goal within a public framework and if we are clear in our direction and then follow through with the goodwill of those who are also involved, we can achieve substantial gains for ourselves and our communities.

I hope this House sees the coming event of the RTA New South Wales bike ride, which will have a great effect on the localised and small communities within my electorate, as a substantial boost to the economies and the small businesses in what is an off-peak tourist period. Our coast is inundated during the Christmas period. Again, at Easter we attract a large number of tourists from the Sydney region and elsewhere. But there is a slight lull in March and this event was timed to capture and continue the employment of those people through what would have been a small lull in the tourist operations. I believe the success of that boost has been very much guaranteed by the amount of work involved.

I would like to pay credit to the councils involved, to the New South Wales Bicycle Institute and to all those who have participated and given their goodwill towards something which is non-political but constitutes an economic advantage for my electorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the misguided decision by federal cabinet in 1945 to develop Kingsford-Smith as an international airport there has been endless controversy. Even in the 1940s it was obviously an unsuitable site, on any unbiased view. For 50 years almost all decision making has been short term and driven by vested interests. It was not until 1980 that the reality was officially recognised in the Sydney region outline plan review as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The present location of the airport (Kingsford-Smith) is inappropriate for a city the size of Sydney: the site is too small, expansion would adversely affect the bay, the port and the surrounding community. Three out of four approach paths to the airport are over dense urban development giving rise to real concern over safety, and the road traffic to serve the airport is causing increasing congestion on the local road system. There is no doubt that a major airport located on a green fields site and connected to inner Sydney by high standard road and rail links is the only solution to catering for Sydney's future airport needs.

That analysis was first made in the 1940s. In 1995 it is now accepted by every thinking person except the vested interests.Yet over the years captive governments and bureaucracies have poured billions of dollars in public subsidies into Kingsford-Smith. Beginning from an area about the size of two football fields, the airport has steadily gobbled up a large part of Sydney. First Ascot racecourse went, then the New Brighton and Bonnie Doon golf courses. Cooks River was moved, two or three lakes filled, a substantial part of Botany Bay taken and a railway line removed. Huge surrounding areas have been taken by airport related infrastructure. Thousands of homes have been demolished. Now hundreds more will be demolished at Sydenham, and thousands more along the flight paths and land transport routes will slowly decay and cease to be livable.

PARA.TAB: It is the single biggest cause of urban sprawl in the metropolitan area except, of course, for the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority. The airport and its adjoining infrastructure are now occupying land on which some 200,000 people could be living at relatively low densities. The fact that 200,000 are instead living on the urban fringe has imposed massive urban consolidation costs on the community—costs which make those of a new airport almost insignificant.

After all this, we have a third rate airport with split passenger terminals, on a minuscule site which cannot even cope with the Olympics and has no long-term future. It suffers enormous air traffic congestion and a permanent curfew. Airline competition is stifled by the outrageous 30-year domestic terminal leases to Ansett and Qantas.

It is a massive health hazard to both passengers and residents alike, located as it is adjoining the Sydney CBD, with the runways aligned with Australia's highest density residential area and a major petro-chemical works: the whole miasma stirred along by the self-serving Federal Airports Corporation—soon to be disbanded—and the Civil Aviation Authority, a shattered and discredited organisation.

The present major health studies being conducted will underline not only the deleterious effects of aircraft noise but the toxic effects of aircraft emissions. In addition, residential areas in inner and middle Sydney are being forced to increase residential densities in a futile attempt to make up for the residential land inexorably lost to the airport.

On any rational basis—economic, social or environmental—it is impossible to keep an expanding international airport in the densest part of Sydney. All that can be done in the short term is: firstly, to implement a range of noise minimisation procedures—not on the inhuman political basis of apportioning as much noise as possible to those in the state and federal seats on the northern flight path, but on the basis of equity; and, secondly, to accelerate the construction of Badgerys Creek as a replacement airport for Kingsford-Smith by, say, 2005.

A twin airport solution is hopeless and the proposal of long-term leasing of Kingsford-Smith to private enterprise would entrench this and all the other problems with no solution possible. It would be uneconomic and inefficient and preclude the massive economic, social and environmental benefits of redeveloping Kingsford-Smith residentially. It is almost beyond belief that in half a century of airport development no cost benefit study has been prepared for this or for the effect on Sydney of any of the major works carried out at the airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week in question time, I asked a question of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe) in respect of the East Perth project which is being carried out in my electorate under the better cities program.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the schedule to the agreement between the Commonwealth and the state of Western Australia. In the schedule to the agreement in respect of the East Perth project, one of the objectives of the project is described as being `to promote and increase housing choice and affordability'. The schedule also states:

SPEECH.PARA: While market housing will be the main emphasis dwellings for public and special needs housing will be purchased and developed. A research and development program will be initiated to establish an appropriate mechanism for the provision of affordable housing.

In August of last year the Deputy Prime Minister visited the East Perth project and, as a result of representations made by me and my state parliamentary colleague, the state member for Perth, Diana Warnock, he publicly repeated on that occasion the Commonwealth's commitment to affordable housing and made representations to the East Perth Redevelopment Authority that affordable housing plans be produced.

PARA.TAB: Following that, on 23 August 1994, in the Guardian Express newspaper, one of my local newspapers, it was stated:
East Perth Redevelopment Authority chief executive Michael Ratcliffe reconfirmed the government's commitment to providing affordable housing but refused to say when or how.
"There are a number of mechanisms currently being examined and specific projects are being formalised."

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of patience but seeing no action, a couple of Sundays ago, on 22 January—and following the release of the first lots of the East Perth project, where vacant lots were sold for hundreds of thousands of dollars, far beyond the reach of ordinary Western Australian taxpayers—bearing in mind, of course, that $100 million worth of taxpayers' funds are going to this project—my state colleague, Diana Warnock and I released a statement where we called upon the Deputy Prime Minister not to provide 1995-96 better cities program funds to Western Australia until the state government had produced its affordable housing plan for East Perth. In the release that day, Diana Warnock and I stated:
We understand that a report from the East Perth Redevelopment Authority is currently languishing before the State Minister for Planning, Richard Lewis.
We understand the report recommends a modest 50 residential units be allocated for affordable housing purposes.

In response to that, the state government, through the Executive Officer of the Redevelopment Authority, publicly said—and I quote from the Channel 10 news on Sunday, 22 January, and repeated on the ABC Radio news on the same day and the ABC Channel 2 TV news:

50's only the first component of a much larger program that we've got planned for providing affordable housing in East Perth. Overall probably by the time the project's fully built out there could be several hundred.
Members will not be surprised to realise that the following day, it was reported in the West Australian of January 23:

PARA.TAB: Mr Smith and Ms Warnock said they welcomed the commitment to 50 affordable units but called on Mr Ratcliffe to release details of the broader picture.

SPEECH.PARA: Following that, on 31 January, page 2 of the Guardian Express, under the heading `Affordable house plans "imminent"', it was stated:
The release of plans showing how affordable housing in the East Perth redevelopment will be provided is "imminent".

PARA.TAB: That's the word from East Perth Redevelopment Authority chief executive officer Michael Ratcliffe
"I can't say exactly when but, yes, it is imminent."

SPEECH.PARA: Following my question to the Deputy Prime Minister this week, I find in the West Australian of Tuesday 7 February, in a report entitled `Snag over housing cash' the following comment from the East Perth Redevelopment Authority Chief Executive Michael Ratcliffe:

PARA.TAB: However, it—

SPEECH.PARA: the authority—
was still negotiating with private companies and could not release the plan until those talks had finished later this year.

So what do I have, Mr Speaker? On 23 January this year I have a comprehensive plan that is in existence; on 31 of January the release of that plan is imminent; and on 7 February that plan is not yet complete and will be released later this year. That tells me a couple of things. It tells me, firstly, that the East Perth Redevelopment Authority is acting under instructions from the state government to drag its feet on affordable housing and not to fulfil its affordable housing commitments; secondly, it tells me that there is no commitment on the part of the state government for affordable housing in East Perth; and, thirdly, it tells me that, unless the state government is relentlessly pursued on this matter, East Perth will become a enclave for the rich and not provide for any reasonable amount of affordable housing.

PARA.TAB: Some people in this business are publicly spirited. I have now in my possession a copy of `East Perth Redevelopment Authority—Affordable Housing in East Perth: A position summary', which was released privately to me because the state government refused to do so. This is an East Perth Redevelopment Authority plan which provides for an `active program of assisted housing which will provide 50 residential units to low and moderate income households in East Perth'. This position paper argues that, because 50 affordable housing units will be erected in the first three years, in accordance with the better cities program, this will result in a rich social mix and `advanced equity and social justice'. `Rich' is the right word. With 50 units out of a $100 million project, it is for the rich. As I have previously, I call upon the state government to release its comprehensive plans now. It cannot get away with this sleight of hand—to use $100 million worth of taxpayers' funds to provide only 50 affordable housing units in East Perth. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, having been identified by Coopers and Lybrand as the third fastest growing area in Australia, the former city of Cranbourne, now part of the city of Casey, has many urgent needs. Some of these are being addressed. I am pleased to say, for instance, that some cooperation between the federal and state governments will see the extension of electric train services to Cranbourne by an expected date of late March this year.

PARA.TAB: However, Cranbourne still lacks a Medicare office. Residents with cash or cheque claims for Medicare, Medibank Private or the new child-care allowance have to travel to the nearest Medicare office at either Parkmore, Keysborough, Frankston or Dandenong. Cranbourne businesses also lose possible takings since the location of a Medicare office can be an important factor in where residents spend their shopping dollars.

I know that the Health Insurance Commission will immediately say, `We have no spare cash to lease and fit out a new office, or to run it with the minimum six staff that we run metropolitan offices with.' May I suggest that, with the Dandenong and Frankston offices both handling in excess of 1,000 claims on many days—the latter having particular difficulties in coping with workloads—any future growth at either of these offices will almost certainly require new office accommodation. Rentals in Cranbourne will typically be cheaper than in Dandenong or Frankston. I agree with the Health Insurance Commission that any new offices must be affordable. Surely, if it can save thousands of dollars through not having to expand in these district centres, that should be a major stumbling block cleared in obtaining the go-ahead for a Cranbourne office.

The proportion of bulk-billing—or, as the commission calls it, direct billing—of patients by medical practitioners is now at a statewide average of almost 60 per cent, but for Cranbourne it is only 45 per cent. It certainly is not correct to assume that all doctors bulk-bill in the outer suburbs. This means that there would most likely be a greater than average number of cash claims at any new Cranbourne office for each 1,000 client visits, at least on the Medicare side of the office's operations—and Medicare typically accounts for 50 to 60 per cent of an office's workload.

Cranbourne has about 10,000 children under the age of five. With about five families moving into the area on a daily basis, it is easy to see that figure rapidly growing. Since many parents will now be claiming the home child-care allowance through Medicare offices, the high percentage of young people in the Cranbourne community further shows the urgent need for a Medicare office in Cranbourne. People from Phillip Island and Wonthaggi presently have to travel to Dandenong to lodge their claims. Not only would their travelling time be reduced but they could also shop in Cranbourne and bring further shopping dollars to Cranbourne.

I also note that the Health Insurance Commission opened a new office at Waurn Ponds last year after many years of pressure from my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) for a facility on the southern side of the Barwon River. I commend my colleague for his efforts. However, while I think we all recognise that area around Geelong to be fast growing, it is outstripped by the rate at which Cranbourne is expanding. If Waurn Ponds can be the recipient of a new office, why not Cranbourne?

I intend to continue pressing this Labor government for a new Medicare office in Cranbourne. The local community urgently needs this facility. Its provision would reduce likely future expenditures elsewhere by the Health Insurance Commission.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRAWN BOAT LEVY BILL 1994Cognate bills:PRAWN EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1994PRAWN EXPORT PROMOTION BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 7 December 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate to make a few remarks to honour Australia's prawn industry. The coalition supports and welcomes the Prawn Boat Levy Bill, the 1994 Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 and Prawn Export Promotion Bill, which are being debated in cognate. The Australian Prawn Promotion Association Limited, which has now existed for four years, has dedicated itself to attempting to arrest the decline in Australia's prawn market share and earnings through direct competition in overseas markets from aquacultured prawns. It is an industry that earns some $179 million a year in export income. Given the current rather precarious state of this nation's balance of trade position, it is entirely appropriate that industries be encouraged to do everything possible to address that situation. That is precisely what the Australian Prawn Promotion Association Ltd is attempting to do with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Faced with difficulties in the industry, the association sought federal government assistance in working to increase the export value of sea caught prawns, particularly in the very important market of Asia, especially Japan. The association has developed what amounts to a self-help strategy and will seek to promote its product in innovative ways which will broadly seek to differentiate Australian sea caught prawns from the overseas farmed product.

The government has agreed to collect funds for the scheme by means of a prawn boat levy and prawn export charge. The following groups have essentially sought and agreed to this approach: the National Fishing Industry Council, Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation, Western Australian Northern Trawler Operators Association, Western Australian Fishing Industry Council, Australian Fisheries Management Authority, Spencer Gulf Association of South Australia, Sharks Bay Association of Western Australia and Northern Prawn Fisheries Queensland Trawl Association. Essentially, given that the government has agreed to collect these funds from the industry, the money collected by the Commonwealth will be paid to the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation which will use those funds specifically for the promotion of sea caught prawns or the product thereof.

All promotional activities must be approved by the Australian Prawn Promotion Association Ltd acting on behalf of its members. The amount of levy will be determined by the Australian Prawn Promotion Association Ltd and prescribed by regulation. However, the maximum permissible amount of levy per boat is $75 for a ship less than 10 metres, $150 for a ship more than 10 metres but less than 15 metres, $300 for a ship more than 15 metres but less than 18 metres and $750 in the case of a ship not less than 18 metres. The amount of the export charge is not to exceed 10c a kilogram of the net weight of the sea caught prawns. There will be an exemption for exporters who export less than 5,000 kilograms of sea caught prawns or their product in a financial year.

The only other comment that I would make is to acknowledge that from time to time the debate is raised as to the appropriateness of industries determining that they want to impose levies on themselves and that, in return for government assistance and contribution towards these schemes, they would bind all of their members—notwithstanding that some members may have different views. That sometimes is seen to be a difficult issue.

I want to say this very clearly: the evidence is quite overwhelming that, where these schemes are properly constructed and where due processes in relation to accountability are maintained, the benefits both to the industry participants and to Australia's economic performance, and in particular to its trade performance, are a substantial improvement on what they might otherwise have been. The nation has, in my view, benefited enormously—particularly in terms of export returns—from, for instance, the research and development grant arrangements that apply to virtually all of our primary industries.

These approaches to date have enjoyed bipartisan support in this place—in recognition, as I say, of their benefit not only to the participants but to the broader community and to Australia's economic performance in general. I hope that that continues to be the case in the future. I do not want to prolong the debate here more than anybody else does; but, given that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) felt no particular need this morning to elaborate in great detail on this legislation, I thought it appropriate to make those comments. We support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In light of the fact that there is a vigorous debate getting under way, it might help the committee if I were to give some greater details as to the government's intentions in introducing this legislation. The purpose of Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994, Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Promotion Bill 1994—which, of course, we are dealing with as a cognate debate—is to provide funding for the export promotion of Australian sea caught prawns.

PARA.TAB: The prawn sector is an important part of the Australian fishing industry, providing significant input to a number of regional economies. In 1992-93, prawn exports totalled $260 million, which is nearly 20 per cent of the total Australian fishing industry GVP. Some 10,000 tonnes of sea caught prawns are exported annually. Over the past few years, market share and earnings have been reduced through direct competition in overseas markets, mainly from aquaculture prawns being produced in Asian countries.

Prices have fluctuated dramatically over the last six years and this has affected all sectors of the industry. All major Australian prawn fisheries are being fished to full capacity and are being carefully managed by state and Commonwealth authorities to ensure sustainability for the industry. Increased catches to counteract falling prices are just not possible. Faced with these pressures, the prawn fishing industry recognised the benefits of developing a structured and coordinated approach to market development. Through the Australian Prawn Promotion Association (APPA), the industry is working to increase the export value of Australian sea caught prawns, especially those sold on the Japanese market.

The industry developed a promotional strategy to contrast Australian sea caught prawns with the Asian farmed product. The strategy aims to make the public aware of the excellent quality of Australian sea caught prawns taken from clean, unpolluted seas. It will also stress specific attributes such as size, flavour and health status. This is a great example of an industry working together to best promote its product in a very competitive market. The promotion plan will be complemented with action in other important areas such as value adding, product quality, freight cost minimisation and reliability of supply.

Following development of the proposal over several years, the vast majority of the Australian prawn industry has called for a compulsory levy on its members to promote its products in export markets, particularly in Japan. APPA has tried introducing voluntary levies, but these did not work, due to a large number of free-riders.

Government support in collecting a levy is not unique to the prawn industry. Within the primary industries and energy portfolio, some 30 compulsory levies or charges are collected by the government to fund promotion and other activities to assist primary industries. Compulsory levies will allow for greater accountability over the use of funds, and ensure that those gaining the greatest benefit from the promotion will make the largest contribution. Given the very strong industry support for the promotion scheme and its funding through a levy, the government was pleased to agree to the industry's request to introduce legislation for a compulsory levy.

The prawn boat levy and the prawn export charge are the two mechanisms by which contributions will be collected. To support APPA in the responsible management of public funds, the Commonwealth's Fisheries Research and Development Corporation will oversight the management and disbursement of the funds collected. APPA will bear the responsibility for determining the promotional activities and the day-to-day running of the scheme. APPA will also provide the FRDC with strategic annual operational plans and annual reports about prawn promotion. These will form a segment of any FRDC reporting requirement.

The government is pleased to allow APPA to be the main player in running the promotion program. The government views this as an important industry initiative, and considers it will prove an important example to other sectors of the fishing industry which are wanting to promote their products.

There are three bills in this package of legislation. The Prawn Export Promotion Bill will provide the administrative framework for collecting, managing and disbursing the prawn promotion funds. The collection arrangements closely mirror those that appear in the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991. This new bill adapts the essential features of the PILCC Act 1991 for the collection of both the prawn export charge and the prawn boat levy.

One of the provisions of this bill will give the secretary to the department the power to conclude an agency agreement with APPA, making it the collecting organisation for the boat levy and the export charge, thus reducing the administrative costs of the scheme. The bills provide for the imposition of two separate types of levies. One levy will apply to boats taking prawns for the export market, and the other will apply to exporters of sea caught prawns and parts of sea caught prawns.

For both the Prawn Boat Export Levy Bill and the Prawn Export Charge Bill, the government has taken account of the user-pays principle by targeting only that sector of the prawn fishing industry that catches prawns for the export markets. Boats that would normally take prawns only for the domestic market are exempt from the levy.

The levy will be payable by the owner of any boat that is licensed to be used to take prawns and is a registered establishment under the Export Control Act 1982. The rate of levy is to be set by regulation, being initially between $50 and $500 per boat per annum, depending on the length of the boat.

There are four categories of boat length levies. A boat less than 10 metres will attract $50; a boat 10 metres but less than 15 metres will attract $100; a boat 15 metres but less than 18 metres will attract $200; and a boat over 18 metres will attract $500.

The legislation provides for a maximum levy rate 50 per cent higher than each of the rates set out above. Pro rata rates of levy will be prescribed in the first year of operation of the act if the act comes into effect part way through a financial year. It is expected that the boat levy will raise some $300,000 during the first full year of its operation.

The Prawn Export Charge Bill proposes that all sea caught prawns, parts of sea caught prawns and sea caught prawn components of products which are exported from Australia be subject to a charge for the funding of the export promotion program. The charge will be paid by the exporter, and will be initially set at 2c per kilogram. Only by industry's recommendation can the rate of the charge be raised by regulation to a maximum of 10c per kilogram. This levy is expected to raise some $200,000 for promotion in the first full year of operation. It is important to note that levy rates for boat lengths and export charges can only be raised following an APPA annual general meeting at which approval is given by members to the new rates of levy.

Honourable members can see that this is valuable and important legislation, and the mere fact that it has been dealt with in this committee in no way indicates that it is anything but a most important piece of legislation. I commend it to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to talk on this very significant piece of legislation. It does affect my electorate, where the prawn industry is a very important one. The Prawn Export Promotion Bill 1994, together with the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994, give effect to an announcement on 13 July by the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) aimed at boosting the promotion of Australia's sea caught prawn exports. This initiative is designed to combat the erosion of the Australian prawn industry's market share and earnings through direct competition in overseas markets from aquaculture prawns.

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing to note that we are also developing an aquaculture prawn industry. Last year, the Minister for Resources visited an aquaculture prawn farm outside Edmonton, in my electorate. The value of aquaculture in Australia is $254 million, but worldwide it is a $43.4 billion industry—and those are 1992 figures. That means that Australia only has 0.5 per cent, in 1992 terms at least, of the world market. This legislation is a direct consequence of the burgeoning world market in aquaculture, and the government's and industry's response to that difficulty.

China now ranks as the top world producer of aquaculture prawns, with 22 per cent of the world output of cultured prawns, and that is expected in the near future to increase to 30 per cent. Other major aquaculture exporting countries are Indonesia, Thailand, Ecuador and Taiwan, and the industry in India is growing. This represents a significant change in these countries, because in the last 20 years there has been a complete shift from captured prawns, which dominated the market in these countries, to aquaculture. And that is the reason the legislation is before the committee today.

There are a lot of problems facing the Australian prawn industry and I am indebted to one of my constituents, Mr Bill Izard, who has written to me, as well as to the federal and state ministers, in relation to a particular problem which I want to raise. That is the problem of the decline in the prawn brood stock population. Mr Izard has been involved in the industry, supplying prawn brood stock to local aquaculture and, to a limited extent, overseas aquaculture. He wrote to me last year and I will quote from the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last four years I have conducted my own prawn tagging study to investigate the size and movements of the Cairns broodstock prawn population. Of great concern is that within six weeks, 20% (a very large proportion) of tagged prawns are captured by vessels fishing the stocks, indicating that the stocks could potentially be easily overfished. If we were to service the overseas markets to the level they currently demand, such overfishing would be very likely. This increased demand from overseas is most likely to occur because our broodstocks have no known diseases and are very attractive to overseas prawn farmers.

It is pleasing to note that controls on export and collection of live prawns in order to control aquaculture brood stock have been suggested by the Australian prawn farmers association. The national agency that is dealing with this matter is the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, and the industry suggestions are being currently reviewed by the Advisory Committee on Live Fish, which advises the ANCA. I thank Mr Izard for raising those concerns, which are significant. He is greatly concerned. In fact, I spoke to him this morning. He is at the moment off the coast of Cairns, at False Cape, trying to find out where the prawn brood stock goes. Apparently, at this time of year it just disappears. That is of concern to the industry and to people like him, who are involved in the general fishing and prawn industry.

PARA.TAB: Another matter is of great concern and should be of concern both to Australian aquaculture and to the world industry. I have mentioned that most of the world's aquaculture supply comes from Asia. There is a great concern that the industry in Asia, to put it very frankly, is not a sustainable industry in terms of the environment. I am indebted to the Parliamentary Library for supplying me with an article by Nigel Forteath, published in Australian Fisheries of March 1993. In this article he highlights a lot of difficulties in relation to the lack of environmental sustainability in terms of aquaculture in South-East Asia. This ought to be of concern to us. It is obviously a reason why we should develop marketing strategies to sell our environmentally clean industry, but also it is a warning to the Australian industry, in terms of aquaculture, not to make the mistakes of Asia. Nigel Forteath says:

SPEECH.PARA: On a recent visit to Asia, the author was surprised to witness the harvesting of prawns for immediate sale which were being fed a diet liberally laced with a chloramphenicol.
That is a growth hormone. He continues:
Australian aquaculturists would do well to promote their management practices in the face of increasing competition from prominent foreign producers.

PARA.TAB: The use of hormones to promote growth in fish is not a new concept but consumer resistance has restricted their use to laboratory trials. It is essential that whenever hormones are used to enhance aquaculture production the public are fully and honestly informed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would totally agree with that. Further on, he says:

In Asia and South America in particular, uncontrolled expansion of intensive coastal aquaculture has resulted in a plethora of disease and water quality problems, to say nothing about the destruction of fish nurseries.
He continues with a very interesting point:
The rapid expansion in prawn culture in Asia may well limit or even destroy itself by auto-pollution. This has occurred already in Taiwan.
A final point is worth making:

Competition for land and water between terrestrial farmers and aquaculturists has been a hall-mark of prawn farming in parts of Asia. In these countries, rich and powerful investors have caused serious problems for villagers by replacing traditional rice farming with ponds or flooding land with saltwater from poorly designed pondages . . . As a result, subsistence economics are in competition with aquaculture.

All this leads to the conclusion that it is obvious that Australia should not follow the model of South-East Asia. These bills will provide the resources in terms of both marketing and research to enable us to develop niche markets and to market our product as clean and environmentally friendly.

PARA.TAB: The fact remains that our competitive edge in terms of international prawn markets is afforded by the pristine waters of the tropical coast—some of which are off my electorate—which harbour some 13 species of commercially fished prawns. These species are the royal red prawn, greasyback prawn, blue endeavour prawn, red endeavour prawn, school prawn, brown tiger prawn, grooved tiger prawn, white banana prawn, red-legged banana prawn, western king prawn, red spot king prawn, eastern king prawn and giant tiger prawn. The aims of the proposed arrangements are to facilitate the opening up of new niche markets overseas and, importantly, the consolidation of existing markets.

As you are no doubt aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the legislative arrangements proposed by these bills, the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994 and Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994, follow the standard for primary industries levies and charges legislation, that is, an administrative act, an imposition act and a collection act. It is important to note that the levy and charge provided by the Prawn Levy Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 have been imposed by the Commonwealth at the request of the Australian Prawn Promotion Association. That follows a request from the prawn industry that a compulsory levy be made on prawn fishermen, processors and exporters to fund export promotional activities.

This package of bills puts into legislation form the APPA's self-help, self-funding promotional program, which is based on levies being paid on the length of boats and the volume of prawns exported. It is an excellent example of aspects of an industry working together to best promote their product to a common market.

There are four categories of annual levy. Boats less than 10 metres in length will attract a $50 levy; between 10 and 15 metres $100; between 15 and 18 metres $200; and over 18 metres $500. Sea caught prawns and parts of sea caught prawns exported from Australia will be subject to a 2c per kilogram charge to be payable by the exporter.

Under the legislation boat levies and export charges can be raised only after the Governor-General has considered recommendations made to the minister by APPA following approval by its annual general meeting. This strategic initiative by the APPA aims to promote Australian sea caught prawns as superior quality prawns caught in pristine Australian seas. The export promotion is aimed mainly at the Asian market. The pristine nature of the water surrounding tropical Australia, as I have said earlier, is our key marketing tool. There is no doubt that Australia's reputation as a clean, safe environment for the production of foodstuffs will grow and become a pivotal marketing quality.

In this respect I want to draw the attention of the House to the need to do everything we can to avoid oil spills in the waters to our north, especially within the Great Barrier Reef. Clearly, an oil spill would cause economic loss as well as incalculable environmental damage.It has been highlighted—and we cannot hide from the fact—that the further up the Great Barrier Reef one goes, the greater the disaster which would have to be dealt with, especially in the area north of Cooktown where there is not a great deal of infrastructure of any sort. An oil spill in that part of the Great Barrier Reef going up to the Torres Strait would obviously be a disaster and one that would be very difficult to deal with.

I am pleased that the industry has seen the benefits of a coordinated and structured approach to generic promotion rather than staying with the fragmentation of the past. I am also pleased that the industry has been vocal on the need to prevent the pollution of the coastline and the reef. The APPA's aims are also consistent with the government's policy of value adding and the `clean green' trade push into Asia. The APPA has assured the government that a majority of its members welcome the promotional activity. It is anticipated that the arrangements will raise some half a million dollars for promotional activities.

The gross value of Australian prawn production is estimated to total $278.107 million and 20,251 tonnes in 1993-94, compared to $282.403 million and 24,440 tonnes in 1992-93. Fisheries within the Commonwealth jurisdiction produce the largest quantity of prawns. The northern prawn fisheries is the principal prawn producing fishery under Commonwealth jurisdiction. The NPF extends from Cape York Peninsula in my electorate to the east to Cape Londonderry, Western Australia, in the west, and of course takes in the Carpentaria prawn fishery. The NPF covers approximately one million square kilometres and produced an estimated catch of 5,789 tonnes, valued at $98.812 million, in 1993-94, compared with a catch of 7,781 tonnes, valued at approximately $100 million in 1992-93.

There are nine species of prawn caught in the NPF but three species, banana, tiger and endeavour prawns, account for approximately 80 per cent of the fishery's catch. Management policies in the NPF were first introduced in the 1970s. The current management scheme incorporates various regulations, including seasonal closures, daylight trawling bans, boat replacement rules, gear restrictions and compulsory pro rata surrender of certain licences to reduce the number of boats operating in the fishery.

In respect of the compulsory surrender of fishing licences in the NPF, the Bureau of Resource Sciences in its fishery status reports of 1993 reported that to improve the economic and biological viability of the NPF the fishery underwent a restructuring intended to reduce fishing capacity by approximately 40 per cent from the 1990 level. A total of 127 vessels fished for prawns in the NPF in 1993, compared with a total of 200 vessels in 1990. The BRS reported in its fishery status reports of 1993 that the NPF is commercially fully exploited. While moves to reduce the number of vessels in the fleet were not met with enthusiasm by the industry, there is little doubt that, for the industry to be sustainable, action had to be taken. It simply does not make economic sense to kill the goose that lays the golden eggs.

The other major prawn fishery under Commonwealth jurisdiction is the Torres Strait prawn fishery. The Torres Strait is in my electorate and is located between the tip of Cape York and Papua New Guinea. The TSPF produced an estimated catch of 1,023 tonnes valued at $9.86 million in 1993-94, compared with a catch of 1,622 tonnes in 1992-93 valued at $13.186 million.

I would like to say a few words in the few minutes I have got left about the Torres Strait Protected Zone Authority, which has introduced management arrangements designed to control fishing effort but not disadvantage existing operations in the Torres Strait prawn fishery. The Torres Strait prawn fishery is the most valuable of all Torres Strait commercial fisheries in terms of the 1991-92 figures. The Torres Strait prawn grounds are distributed through the Torres Strait protected zone and `the outside but near areas'.

The majority of the Torres Strait is closed to prawn trawling, mostly on industry initiative. The areas to the west and south-west of the Warrior Reefs, including the water around Sue, Yam, Badu, Moa, Mabuiag and Gabba islands and as far south as the tip of Cape York, are also closed to prawn trawling because of the abundance of juvenile prawns in those grounds. Concerns from the Island Coordinating Council and the removal of the non-transferability provisions in 1992 combined to necessitate the introduction of the new management arrangements for the fishery in 1993.

This bill provides for a sustainable future for Australia's fishing industry. As I said earlier, the industry, which is based mainly in Asia, cannot be seen as a particularly clean industry in relation to aquaculture. Nevertheless, it is expanding. We have got to respond to that expansion. To do that you need both promotion and research and development. To do that you have got to have dollars, and that is what this legislation is about. It has got the support of industry and it has got the support of both sides of parliament. It will provide, I am confident, a prosperous and sustainable future for Australia's prawn industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make some brief comments in support of this legislation. It is always helpful to be speaking on legislation that has bipartisan support in this House. The Prawn Export Promotion Bill 1994, the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 are all aimed at supporting our domestic prawn industry, which, as previous speakers have said, is a valuable part of our fishing export industry. I note that, while we have the third largest fishing zone in the world, we rank only 50th in fisheries production.

PARA.TAB: The big picture shows that the gross value of Australian fisheries production in 1993-94 was $1,606 million, representing a seven per cent increase in value over the previous year. However, in relation to the prawn industry the picture has not been quite so bright. The export value of prawns in 1993-94 was $197 million, as previous speakers have said, but that is a decrease over the previous years, both in volume of production and in returns to Australia.

We should be aware that Australia is also an importer of prawns, and that, in 1993-94, we imported 12,870 tonnes of prawns which were worth $101 million. Thailand is one of the countries which exports prawns to Australia, and this country is one of the largest suppliers. Australia not only has the problem of competing in the export market, but also has the problem of being an importer for the country's domestic needs. Apart from the focus of this legislation, in the promotion of our own excellent quality prawns to the Asia-Pacific markets we have to look at developing our own aquaculture industry to fill the domestic gap. It would seem to me to be a valuable opportunity to promote regional development and to improve the economy, certainly in northern Australia. We have here an opportunity to meet our needs and to promote regional industry. As an aside, I mention that the University of Central Queensland has a small aquaculture project. This is the type of initiative that should be encouraged.
Obviously, Japan is one of our chief markets for seafood. I want to quote from Australian Fisheries, June 1990, Volume 49, No. 6. Referring to the year 1989, the authors said:

SPEECH.PARA: The demand for Australian prawns in Japan—our main export market—declined markedly. Spectacular growth in Asian aquaculture production and subsequent increases in Japanese prawn imports lead to the quantity of prawns in cold storage reaching record levels. . . . Japan is Australia's major seafood export market, accounting for nearly 60 per cent of Australia's seafood exports in 1988-89.

At that stage, Australia's prawn sales to Japan amounted to approximately 8.3 kilotonnes, but our share of the prawn market is declining. The authors suggested that, apart from competition from aquaculture, there is some competition from changing domestic requirements in Japan. Further on in the article, the authors state:

Fundamental changes in Japanese eating habits are also likely to be affecting the demand for prawns. . . . In particular, household consumption of seafood is decreasing among young people. If they continue to favour alternative products to seafood, then seafood demand could fall as the population ages, with potentially serious implications to Australian exports.

One of the reasons for this situation is the change in eating habits of Japanese people, and their move from seafood to beef. There is not only a change in terms of household food production, but also an increasing trend in Japan towards the production of takeaway food. That trend may be very positive for our beef industry, but it probably will not be helpful to our prawn exporters.

PARA.TAB: Other issues which must be taken into consideration are the costs of the two industries. If we compare the cost to process prawns caught off our coastline with the cost of aquaculture, the figures are interesting. I quote again from the article:

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult for Australian prawn fishermen to compete on a price basis with the aquaculture producers in Asia. Production costs for Asian farmed prawns were about $5.00 per kg in 1989. . . . This contrasts with average Australian production costs in the northern prawn fishery (NPF) of about $10.00 per kilogram in 1989.

Obviously, it is going to be a problem for the industry to remain viable. We have to look for niche markets that stress the particular qualities of our seafood production. That will inevitably involve issues such as environmental standards and the post-catch processing and transportation of our seafood.

PARA.TAB: In relation to this bill, the industry requested government assistance when it found that attempting to voluntarily collect the levy was not successful. It is another example of the government consulting with industry to provide an efficient way in which the industry can gather funds to provide effective promotion for its product. There is no doubt that where an excellent quality product exists and is marketed successfully there will be a market for it, particularly in overseas restaurant sectors.

One of the issues which concerns producers in my electorate of Capricornia at this point is the fact that production has dropped over the last two years. This would seem to relate to the drought conditions in central Queensland. In my discussions with them the old saying that came very much to the fore was that a drought on the land is a drought at sea. The reason for that is that there has not been enough rain to wash the eggs out of the estuaries for spawning and then there is not enough water for the baby prawns to swim back into the estuaries to grow. So, while the drought is now affecting our balance of payments, as has been indicated in statements by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the last two sitting weeks, it is clear that here is yet another side effect of the drought conditions as they affect central Queensland.

There have also been some problems with the weather. The boats have been unable to get out. A number of independent fishermen and producers in the Yeppoon area have stopped work altogether. Most of the prawns sold at our local co-op at Rosslyn Bay are for the domestic market. If tiger prawns or king prawns are caught, they are usually sold through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to overseas markets through a southern buyer.

There are also value added and processing operations in my electorate. Tony Newton, from Tanby Seafoods, supports the concerns of the Rosslyn Bay Fishermen's Cooperative Association. To meet the domestic market, he has been forced to buy green prawns out of Townsville or Cairns prawns which come from the northern region. There are then increased prices and people are less prepared to purchase. So, from our local perspective, the drought has had a major impact. Indeed, in the longer term we have to look at land management because that will affect the flow-on through coastal river systems to those estuaries.

The other issue that will be of longer term importance to industries such as the prawn industry is the way we look after our coastal areas. This was alluded to by my colleague the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). Issues such as removing mangroves from coastal areas and beachfront developments all affect the future production of the fishing industry.

As a community and as a country, we have to put a lot of effective forward planning into coastal management to make sure that local government does not allow domestic development on foreshores, dunal areas and estuaries that is going to impact on what is a very important industry, and potentially a very important export industry, for Australia—the fishing industry.

This does echo the concerns of a number of conservation groups. It is important that, rather than this issue becoming a political football, we sit down and carefully plan the way we are going to promote ecologically sustainable development right around the coastline of this country. Increasingly, we will have to look at industries such as fishing to provide jobs for people, to provide export income and value-added industries. That means that the industry and governments have to work together to make sure that we do not overfish and deplete our stocks. This is an issue of some concern because, as in the case I mentioned in my own electorate, when the prawns are not there, there is nothing to fish and people are forced out of the industry temporarily, or sometimes permanently. In order to have a sustainable industry, we must harvest it correctly. This should involve state and federal departments of primary industry working with producer organisations, which has been the case.

This is a very positive initiative by the industry. However, having provided effective promotion, what we have to look at in the long term is the development of our own aquaculture—which, I believe, can be competitive with overseas—not only to meet our own domestic demands, but to provide volume for our exports. I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up its allocated subscription to the fourth general capital increase of the Asian Development Bank—ADB. This means Australia would subscribe to 102,370 shares, of which only 2,047 shares will be paid in at a cost of $US24.69 million.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will be aware that the bank, which was established in 1966, is a major multilateral development finance institution engaged in promoting social and economic advancement in the Asia-Pacific region. Major borrowers include the People's Republic of China, Indonesia and India. The bank has 55 member countries from within and outside the region. The bank's capital is of two kinds: paid-in and callable. The capital increase involves actual payment by members of the paid-in component, and a potential liability for the callable component. The callable component of the bank's capital serves as collateral against which the bank borrows funds for on-lending. The bank's loans have been financed largely by funds borrowed from international financial markets. A call on the callable capital of the bank has never been made. The bank's prudent financial policies and healthy level of reserves make it unlikely that such a call will ever be made in the future.

Under the bank's articles of agreement, the maximum amount of funds the bank can lend cannot exceed the total amount of its unimpaired subscribed capital, reserves and surplus. In March 1994 the bank reached its lending limit and stopped making new loan commitments. In May 1994, the ADB Board of Governors approved a resolution authorising a general capital increase which doubles the share allocation from 1,720,497 shares to 3,440,994 shares. This will allow the bank to expand its borrowings and so finance the bank's operations to beyond the year 2000 and allow the bank to pursue its development objectives in the region.

Under the general capital increase, Australia is entitled to subscribe to an additional 102,370 shares. Only two per cent of these shares need to be paid in. As a result of the low paid-in component, the annual cost of the subscription accounts for a very small part of Australia's aid budget. In supporting the bank, Australia recognises the significant contribution it has made to developing countries in Asia. In pursuing its original prime objective of economic growth and poverty alleviation, the bank has also emphasised private sector development, public sector efficiency, human resource development and natural resource management.

More recently, at the urging of Australia and other donor countries, the bank is paying greater attention to environmental and social problems. In fact, the agreement of several donor countries to adopt the resolution for an additional share allocation was conditional upon the adoption of a policy statement to guide the bank's operations in the 1990s. This statement emphasises initiatives to strengthen the planning process in the bank, incorporating cross-cutting concerns such as poverty, population, women in development, social sector investment and the environment, and addressing new policy issues such as good governance, disclosure of information and the establishment of an inspection function to review potential non-compliance of bank policies.

Most of these initiatives have either been implemented or are in the process of being implemented. The bank has now established a fifty-fifty mix between traditional projects which emphasised economic growth and those projects which are aimed at poverty reduction, human resource development, women in development and environmental protection. The main way in which the bank assists its developing country members is by providing loans for economic and social infrastructure development.

Between 1966 and 1993, the bank provided its member countries with loans totalling $US32.8 billion from its ordinary capital resources. The bank's lending is primarily to the public sector. However, some direct and indirect funding of the private sector has also been undertaken. The bank's lending activities have focused on projects in the agriculture, energy, finance, transport and communications and social infrastructure sectors.

In addition to its financing activities, the bank plays an important role in providing advice on economic policies, sector restructuring and institutional development in developing member countries. Policy reform measures relating to macro-economic policies, sector programs and projects are usually associated with the bank's lending activities and are aimed at improving economic growth prospects, ameliorating poverty and addressing social inequities.

The economic policies promoted by the bank are outward looking and consistent with the development of open international trade and financial markets. Through its lending and technical assistance activities, the bank supports the strengthening of institutions which are essential for economic and social advancement.

Australia's participation in the bank allows us to pursue our economic, political and humanitarian interests in collaboration with other donor and developing countries. The bank's activities have complemented Australia's bilateral aid program in a number of countries, most particularly in Cambodia, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific island countries and Vietnam. Participation in the Asian Development Bank has also allowed us to widen the focus of our aid at a relatively low administrative cost. Australian membership of the bank entitles Australian suppliers of goods and services to bid for work generated under bank financed activities.

In the past five years, loan disbursements by the bank have averaged $US2.6 billion per year. This provides a sizeable commercial opportunity for Australian firms. The most significant benefit to Australia from the bank's activities, however, is not direct procurement from bank projects but the wider export opportunities for Australian businesses deriving from economic growth promoted by the bank in the Asia-Pacific region.

Australian exports to the developing member countries of the bank increased from $12.7 billion in 1988-89 to $23 billion in 1992-93. As a proportion of total Australian exports, exports to those countries rose from 29 per cent to 38 per cent during this five-year period. There is enormous potential for further exports as economic growth in the region continues. Australia is a founding member of the ADB and a strong supporter of it. At the same time, Australia has not been uncritical of the bank where criticism has been justified and it has been pressing the bank to improve its efficiency and effectiveness.

In response to concerns expressed by Australia and other countries about the quality of bank loans, in 1993 the bank established a task force to provide recommendations for improving project quality. Following the report of the task force in early 1994, the bank has taken measures to improve the quality of projects. As recommended by the task force, the bank is currently reviewing its organisational structure to make it more relevant to its strategic objectives and to improve the quality of its projects through improved coordination of its project and program work, greater attention to project implementation vis-a-vis project approvals, strengthening of project executing agencies in the borrowing countries, and improved accountability for the quality of projects within the ADB.

I believe that the economic and political significance of the Asia-Pacific region to Australia and the important developmental role which the Asian Development Bank is playing in the region amply justify Australia's continuing support of the bank by taking up the 102,370 shares of the bank's general capital increase. I commend the bill to honourable members and I now present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994 was introduced into the House on 24 August last year. The coalition does not oppose the bill. This bill empowers the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to make the necessary agreement with the Asian Development Bank for the purchase by Australia of its entitlement of 2,047 additional paid-in shares, and 100,323 additional callable shares, of the capital stock of the bank.

PARA.TAB: The bill also empowers the Treasurer to make this agreement on such terms and conditions as the Treasurer determines and, where appropriate, to issue promissory notes to the bank in payment. This bill also appropriates the funds necessary to make payments under such agreements.

The ADB is a major institution in Australia's multilateral development program. It provides loans, policy advice, equity finance and technical assistance to developing member countries of the Asia-Pacific region.
