The bank has 53 member countries from within and outside this region. Australia already holds 102,370 shares in the bank valued at $US1.406 billion and that represents just over six per cent of the total capital subscribed to the bank. Of this figure, $US168.8 million has been paid to the bank, with the remaining $US1.237 billion subject to call.

Australia is the fourth largest regional shareholder in the Asian Development Bank, the fifth largest overall and a founding member of the bank. During 1993 a central issue before shareholders was the negotiation of the fourth capital increase. This proved difficult because of differences of view on the size and financial conditions applying to an increase in the capital base and on certain conditions which some shareholders sought to attach to bank policies in supporting a capital increase.

In May 1994 the board of governors of the bank adopted resolution No. 232 to increase authorised capital by 100 per cent to $US48.8 billion with a paid-in component of just two per cent. Australia has supported a general capital increase in the bank and the Treasurer, Australia's representative on the board of governors, cast his vote in favour of the resolution on a general capital increase.

The total cost of 2,047 paid-in shares is $US24.69 million. This amount is payable over a 10-year period. The value of 1,323 callable shares is $US1,210.25 million. Fortunately, I believe these callable shares will only become payable if the ADB faces a collapse of a very serious magnitude, and we all hope that that does not happen and presumably believe it is not in prospect. These callable shares are a safeguard for the ADB which should never need to be called upon.

Although the ADB has no doubt been responsible in the past for making a minor positive contribution to developing nations in the Asia-Pacific region, it is likely that Australia can better utilise its foreign aid resources by using different methods. The ADB as well as the World Bank seems to spend an inordinate amount of its money on administration. As members are aware, the Asian Development Bank is based in Manila. The building it occupies cost $US172 million, it has marble corridors and fine artworks adorn the walls. The building is in a city where there are constant brownouts due to a shortage of electricity generation. But the ADB headquarters is not affected by that; it sensibly has its own stand-by generators.

In 1992 it was reported that for the ADB's 1,600 employees there were more than 300 Mercedes cars with all the cars out of the car park by 5 p.m. The salary range was $US40,000 to $US120,000 which for non-Americans and Filipinos was tax free. There are also housing and education subsidies on offer. No doubt they now receive much more rewarding remuneration packages, but no fringe benefits tax. Lucky them!

It sounds like a very nice lifestyle, but at the end of the day the ADB is supposed to be about assisting economic growth in developing Asia-Pacific countries and alleviating poverty. No doubt there is a great wastage of funds at the ADB: funds which could be used to improve the livelihood of many, many more people. The question must therefore constantly be asked: is the ADB a worthwhile recipient of part of our aid budget? The Australian Council for Overseas Aid, ACFOA, and Community Aid Abroad, CAA, both lament contributions made to multilateral development banks, or MDBs, including the Asian Development Bank.

ACFOA estimates that the proportion of the total aid budget going to the MDBs will increase from about 10 per cent to 18 per cent over the coming years. CAA maintains that the proportion of the aid budget going to these multilateral development banks must remain at its current percentage of the aid budget. For CAA, if the commitments to the MDBs continue to increase then all other parts of the aid program should receive commensurate increases in funding to maintain what CAA sees as the ideal mix. Of course, Community Aid Abroad has a vested interest in advocating an increase and pushing for increased funding for non-government organisations or NGOs, as it could expect to be a leading beneficiary.

The coalition is of the view that too many of our foreign aid dollars go to the MDBs. However, we reject the abhorrence by the NGOs of the government's focusing Australia's aid program on specific regions to complement our foreign affairs and trade interests. In that we depart from the NGOs and their views. If Australia is to provide foreign aid, it should be done in a way that maximises the benefit to the recipients, and it should be in Australia's interests.

The government claims that the ADB is a major catalyst in promoting the development of the most populous and fast growing region in the world today, thereby implying that the massive economic growth in our region is attributable in some measure to the ADB. It should be readily apparent that the massive economic growth in our region is due principally to private domestic capital formation and foreign direct investment from private sector sources. The significance of this is that it is frequently argued that foreign aid is essential to capital formation; which, in turn, is essential to wealth creation. In fact, capital formation is the result of economic growth, not its precursor. The economic development of the West was not underpinned by foreign aid, nor is the bulk of economic development in our region due to foreign aid. Indeed, Asia-Pacific governments and businesses can readily borrow funds, both domestically and internationally, from private sector sources—assuming always that the projects for which they are seeking support are productive and the country concerned does not have an overly restrictive foreign investment regime.

The contribution to the economic development of our region of the concessional finance that is disbursed by the Asian Development Fund, the ADF, is thus limited to the savings made by borrowings from the ADF rather than from private sector sources, with the difference being paid for by taxpayers of the shareholding nations. The contribution of such foreign aid to economic development is therefore minimal. Moreover, it may well be that these savings do not offset the costs involved, because some of this capital is lost to the supporting bureaucracies involved in administering the donor's aid programs, as well as by the recipient governments' administrative excesses. Many, even most, of the recipient governments to which we dispense foreign aid in this way are notorious for the misallocation of these funds.

The annual report to this parliament, Australia and the Asian Development Bank 1993, makes it clear that the performance of the bank in picking winners is not terribly good. Of those projects that had their performance evaluated in 1993, only 62 per cent were deemed to have been `generally successful'. I pose the question: what does `generally successful' mean. Only 30 per cent or whatever per cent were actually successful. The term `generally successful' is obviously used to obfuscate the actual lack of success by the ADB and its inability to choose which projects warrant ADB funds.

The ADB must also rate its projects in terms of whether they were totally successful. Only then will the post-project evaluations have real meaning. Only 22 per cent of projects were found to be partly successful, and 15 per cent were unsuccessful. These figures indicate that a minimum of 38 per cent of the projects funded through the ADB were less than fully successful.

It is interesting to note that, in agriculture, the ADB appears to have no ability to differentiate between good projects and bad. In agriculture in 1993, only 40 per cent of projects were generally successful; 40 per cent were partly successful and 20 per cent were unsuccessful. Of course, in developing nations most poverty occurs in rural areas, where successful aid programs can have a real impact on the quality of life of a great number of people. It is an indictment of the ADB that in agriculture it is such a failure.

The ADB has traditionally not been a significant lender to the private sector, as it has preferred to target public sector infrastructure projects. However, the bank—at its last annual general meeting, held in May 1994—stated that it intended to turn increasingly to private sector financing to keep Asia-Pacific economies on the road to growth. Andrew MacCathie, writing in the Financial Review on 6 May wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Private bankers from the world's principal financial markets have increasingly questioned the ongoing role of a multi-national institution, such as the ADB, operating in a region characterised by extraordinary economic growth and an accumulation of wealth. The intense western interest in investing in the region has already helped to prise open, for many Asian Pacific nations, the international private loan and financing markets.
Clearly, Mr Deputy Speaker, many nations in the region are now internally generating or attracting sufficient capital, or have access to offshore financial markets.

PARA.TAB: What role is left for ADB? If we were really interested in the development of the private sector in developing countries, we would facilitate its access to foreign direct investment from private sources by having the ADB and other international financial institutions pull out of international capital markets. If anything, concessional lending by the ADB through the ADF encourages the recipient countries to maintain restrictive foreign investment regimes, so that their governments can maintain control of the bulk of the foreign investment activities in those countries and obtain investment on concessional terms. Where the ADB provides loans for projects intended to alleviate poverty, this should be only undertaken in those countries that have pro-economic growth policies.

ADB assistance to governments in developing countries ignores the fact that it is often those very same governments that are responsible for the impoverished state of their people. While lending to non-government organisations can be an effective way of bypassing the destructive policies of such governments, lending to the governments themselves is effectively a pat on the back for their policies and may even assist them in pursuing those failed policies.

It is difficult to conceive how official development assistance can help alleviate poverty in countries with governments that systematically impoverish their people in the quest for political and economic control. These governments also often maintain large military establishments, further underlining their own lack of commitment to poverty alleviation.

India, for example, has been undertaking a massive militarisation expansion in recent decades. In 1991 India's military expenditure as a proportion of its gross domestic product was 50 per cent greater than Australia's. India has a blue water navy, which includes two aircraft carriers, and I understand there is a third on order. These are armed forces of a dimension about which Australia can only dream. China also has a massive military machine and, unlike India, is a totalitarian dictatorship. China is also rapidly developing a blue water navy, which will enable it to project power and influence well into our region.

Nations which can put large levels of national resources into the military and into repressive state organs do not deserve to receive concessional loans or even loans at commercial rates from the ADB for projects that might not otherwise qualify for commercial financing from other non-MDB institutions.

The ADB might very well lend for specific non-military purposes, but the implication of that for spending on military might, as it were, is that it takes the onus off the governments of such countries to provide funding which the ADB substitutes. So they are then able to appropriate internally generated wealth into the military machines that have the potential to grow. The People's Republic of China, Vietnam and India have three of the largest standing armies in the world. They are right up there in the top 10.

It is not the role of taxpayer funded MDBs to prop up profligate governments, and I am sure other taxpayers in other nations that provide capital to the ADB would agree with this if they knew it was happening. Official development assistance should follow political and economic liberalisation rather than precede it if it is to have any hope of achieving meaningful poverty alleviation. It is clear that Australia needs to conduct a detailed review of its aid program and its role in multinational development banks and agencies. This review must examine the arrangements under which the aid budget could best help developing nations and also what is in Australia's best interests.

The coalition believes that Australia's foreign aid program must take into account more selective criteria than are applied at the moment. There is a need to focus on our region, the Asia-Pacific, reflecting our foreign policy and trade priorities. The main objective of our foreign policy should be to build strong and substantial bilateral ties with our neighbours. To do that it might very well be wise to go to programs of bilateral aid rather than laundering part of our aid package through these international financial institutions.

The government seems more interested in multilateral relations and funding through such agencies as the ADB and conducting its affairs through the United Nations, which provide it with a glamorous but wasteful footing on the world stage. The real work to further Australia's interests, both national security and economic, must be centred on regional bilateral ties. Consequently, our foreign aid program needs to complement our foreign policy. Our aid program must focus on our region.

This should be based on a hard-headed foreign policy which is based in turn upon enlightened self-interest—to identify Australia's changing national interests and to put those interests first. We reject Labor's contention that we must be seen to be good international citizens, and instead maintain that we should look after our own backyard, where we can best have a real impact.

This policy approach, however, should not be implemented at the cost of emergency and humanitarian aid, which the coalition believes should be maintained. That is in a different category altogether and is not included in my criticism. There must be increased emphasis on the alleviation of poverty and the delivery of services through the NGOs. Delivering aid through NGOs is a quite effective way of bypassing the destructive policies of some governments and getting maximum value for our aid dollar. Unfortunately, even NGOs can stuff up.

The Australia-China Council is providing $300,000 per annum to fund the Australian Studies Centre at the East China Normal University, in Shanghai. Apparently, the centre is staffed by one Australian academic, occupying one spartanly furnished room with a few books and teaching 50 Chinese students.

One of the Australian academics employed during the Tiananmen Square democracy demonstrations became actively involved in supporting the student movement. I am told—reliably, I believe—that the $300,000 used to fund the centre was used not only to pay the salary of the academic employed but also to provide corrupt university administrators with a bit of a good time, including eating and drinking very well indeed. Such goings-on, I presume, are not the norm. Apparently the consulate in Shanghai knows what is happening in the Australian Studies Centre but has done or can do little about it. If this account which I have is accurate, it is a wasteful use of taxpayer funds and it should be stopped.

Preference should be given to bilateral aid and the provision of Australian goods and services. Bilateral aid is an effective method of strengthening our relations with countries in our region. By encouraging the provision of Australian goods and services there is still a shift of taxpayer funds offshore, but at least some of the percentage is expended in Australia, providing jobs for Australians. Provision of Australian goods and services can in some circumstances encourage future trade. This is certainly better than our aid being used to purchase goods and services from other countries, with no benefit for Australia.

Aid should not be applied in ways which support repressive governments or those with excessive military expenditure. The economic policies of the recipient country should be taken into account, giving preference to those countries that encourage economic freedom of their population.

What I refer to as laundering of part of our aid program through international financial institutions is a very convenient way of getting around the criticisms which would be levelled at us for providing funds in certain circumstances to certain countries whose records on human rights are not very good. We get a bit holier than thou in some cases when talking about human rights in other countries. Whilst our open aid program can be modified according to our public rhetoric of objection to human rights activities in certain countries, moneys going through such institutions as the one we are talking about today are not identified with Australia and, therefore, we can escape some legitimate criticism for having double standards about human rights in countries in our region.

Those countries which encourage economic freedom and pursue economic growth strategies are the countries which should receive first priority in our allocation of foreign aid which is channelled in this way. To provide aid to countries which have no regard for market or economic freedom will only encourage those countries to remain inefficient and will only reinforce their dependency on foreign aid. Foreign aid should be used to reward those countries that are implementing policies that are geared towards economic growth.

The provision of aid to those countries will, in the long term, also assist a move towards a democratic political system in the country receiving aid. Additional funding by Australia of the Asian Development Bank does little to further Australia's interests and provide a good means of delivering aid. The Australian Labor Party appears to be obsessed by the ADB because it is the sole multilateral agency in which Australia is a major player.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true. What about the IMF and the World Bank?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Fraser will have an opportunity to participate in a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true. The ALP is obsessed with it. The ALP does not appear prepared to give up the spotlight, even if the need for the ADB is now highly questionable. There is a certain amount of spotlighting in this. It is stage strutting. However, my view is that we would be far better off, in most cases and with most international financial institutions, redirecting the cost of shares—or however we finance those institutions—into a bilateral aid program where we have control over, and get the credit for, the funds made available by this country.

PARA.TAB: Funds channelled through the IFIs are really not identifiable with Australia. We get absolutely no credit for them. Whilst that is convenient in cases where countries with human rights records which we criticise are funded through the ADB and others—because it alleviates any criticism of us because our involvement is not direct and is not known—it is really not a very brave approach. If we are going to give aid we should be open about it, and the best way to do that is through bilateral aid. We take the criticisms that come with that and we get the credit, not only in the country which receives the aid but internationally, and it is there and open for everyone to see.

There are other reasons which I have advanced before—and which I am sure the honourable member opposite has heard—for not having any great regard for the World Bank and its various agencies. I cannot cover that today. However, generally speaking, I believe we should rely more on bilateral aid and reduce our commitments to these institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst listening to the speech of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), I was hoping to be able to say what an interesting speech it was. There were many valuable points in it, but he finished on a very negative note which I found quite disappointing. He has missed the value of the multilateral development banks. However, he made a complex speech and I will try to comment on a number of aspects of it.

PARA.TAB: There are two or three major justifications for the multilateral development banks, which really make them very cost-effective ways of giving aid. The principal one is that, for a relatively small capital contribution, the banks are enabled to borrow very large amounts of capital, at very low interest rates, on international financial markets, and channel that capital into development work in countries which need it. Really, our aid funds, which are a relatively small element of our total aid package, are multiplied in their value through the funds that can be borrowed commercially and then lent to the developing countries. The benefit to them is that they can borrow from the Asian Development Bank and the other multilateral development banks at interest rates that are rather lower than they themselves would be able to borrow at on the international financial markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can subsidise interest rates—
—No. They are not subsidised—
—Yes, they are—at a cost to the taxpayers.
—Order! Both honourable members know that their comments should be directed through the chair.
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am happy to address my comments through you.
—I concede that my remarks should have been principally addressed to the member for Curtin, in this instance.
—I accept them, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—The principal point is that, because the Asian Development Bank has government guarantees, it is enabled to borrow, strictly commercially, at significantly lower rates than those which countries the credit of which is not nearly as secure are able to borrow at. Therefore, it assists their capital raising at a significantly lower cost than would otherwise be possible. So there is a very sound financial reason for channelling funds in that way.

PARA.TAB: I do accept that the Asian Development Bank and the other multilateral development banks are far from being above criticism. Some of the criticisms that the honourable member for Curtin made are well stated, and I know that even our executive director at the Asian Development Bank would accept some of those. I think some of the figures that were quoted by the honourable member were, in fact, from Asian Development Bank publications, so the bank itself does recognise major problems which it has. The fact of that recognition is an encouraging feature of its work, because it means that it is trying to identify its problems and improve on them.

I will come to a few other points as I go, but I would like to begin my own remarks by saying that I am delighted to strongly support this bill, because I think it is important to try to increase the funds that are flowing to countries where there is still a large problem of impoverishment. That still does exist in our region. I did sometimes wonder, when the honourable member for Curtin was speaking, which region it was that he was talking about. Some of the remarks he made might have better fitted the development banks in Africa or Latin America than those in Asia. One or two points, which I will come to, were well targeted—in particular, his point about military expenditure. But, in Asia, most countries are growing very rapidly and most have reasonably responsible economic policies. Many do not have the quality of human rights that we in Australia would like to see, that is certainly true, but they are adopting policies which are stimulating very rapid economic development.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not need help, then.

—But they do need help. That is, perhaps, the next point I should come to, because there is still a strong imperative for the kinds of lending that the Asian Development Bank does. There is still, in many countries in the region, a major problem of large-scale poverty. Indonesia, for example, has had a very good record of reduction of poverty during the last 30 or 40 years of its independence. It has steadily and quite effectively reduced the level of poverty. But there are still 30 million people living in absolute poverty in Indonesia. It is a rapidly growing country, but its population is also very rapidly growing, so it is very difficult for that country to grow sufficiently fast to raise per capita income at a rate that will continue to rapidly reduce its problem with poverty.

PARA.TAB: Indonesia needs external funds in order to build the infrastructure and to train the people. It also needs the funds to ensure that small-scale credit is available for small-scale business, for land reform and for all of the other essential aspects of an appropriate economic development policy. The Asian Development Bank has had a very significant role in Indonesia. It also has a very useful role in many other countries in the region. If we are seriously concerned about poverty reduction and reduction of unemployment—in other words, the more effective use of the human resources of those countries enabling more fulfilling lives for those people—we should be aiming to ensure that the funds available to them are maximised and are available at the lowest rate that is possible. There are two very good reasons why we should continue to support the Asian Development Bank, and that is one. The second is the growing interdependence of the region, and that is now clear to everyone in Australia.

The Assistant Treasurer, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), in his second reading speech referred to the growth of trade in the region. I will not refer to it again, as the situation was well-described by him. There has been very strong growth in Australian exports to the countries of the region during the last decade and that has been of great benefit to us. It is also of benefit to them. Because their economies are growing strongly, the markets for our goods are expanding strongly and that is essential for us at a time when, as we all know, we have a current account problem. It is very important that we increase even further our exports to the region and that is where our opportunity for export growth is strongest. The faster the economies of those countries grow, the greater the opportunity for us to export to them, and we should be aiming to facilitate that growth, in so far as we have any influence over it. It is also true that, globally, countries are increasingly interdependent, not only through trade but through investment, through financial issues, and even through migration and tourism.

I will come back to the financial question in a moment but, before I do, I want to say a little more about the Asian Development Bank. The bank is certainly not above criticism. It has been remarked quite often that it is a relatively privileged organisation working in the midst of poverty, and certainly that is true of Manila. That does not mean that its staff should not be paid adequate salaries, but it can be argued that the staff are paid rather higher salaries than would be warranted. This point has also been made in relation to the staff of the World Bank.

As I understand it, the Asian Development Bank has been paring off a little of the additional pay that its staff receive, and that is to be welcomed. I hope that members of its staff, like those of the World Bank, are now flying business class rather than first class. Those sorts of changes, which will not significantly undermine the quality of its working life, are important as a way of demonstrating to shareholders that the funds that are made available are used as effectively as possible.

It has been said that the bureaucracy within the Asian Development Bank is rather sheltered, that it does not get out enough, and that it is not sensitive enough to the problems of poverty, unemployment and inequity with which it has to deal. I do not have enough personal experience of the ADB to know whether that is true but, since it is said authoritatively by people who do, one would hope that that has been looked at and that ways of increasing the sensitivity of staff are being examined. However, it has to be said that much that the ADB does is very worthwhile. I have seen some evidence of that in Papua New Guinea. I know of it in some other countries and I think, for the reasons that I gave at the beginning of this speech, we should be strongly supporting the ADB and our contribution to it. It is a cost-effective way of ensuring that our aid funds are well used.

I am well aware that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid would like to see a larger proportion of our aids funds going in bilateral aid and in support of non-government organisations. The answer to that criticism, of course, is that our total aid funding ought to be growing faster, and that is something that I and the honourable member opposite, and others I know, do advocate. It is difficult for governments to increase aid funds at a time when they are trying to minimise outlays. But in an increasingly interdependent world, where we have to recognise that poverty in our neighbouring country is equivalent to the kind of poverty that existed in Britain at the time that Dickens was writing and when we are made aware of that with as much vividness as were the English when Dickens was writing, we have no alternative—if we are going to be decent human beings—but to make our contribution to poverty reduction.

So there is a very strong imperative for maintaining and increasing our aid budget. But there is also that self-interested reason I gave earlier, which should not be forgotten either. I hope that we will continue to increase our total aid budget and, in doing that, increase the amount going in bilateral aid and through non-government organisations, as well as taking up our full entitlement to this new ADB subscription.

There has been a lot of criticism of the development banks in recent years, and I am delighted to see from the Assistant Treasurer's speech that some of that is being reflected in what the government is now saying about the development banks. The criticisms have included that they have not been transparent enough; that they have not been accountable enough; and that they have been too preoccupied with particular, narrow approaches to economic policy which have neglected the environment, or women, or equity, or even poverty. I think they are, at least rhetorically, expressing greater awareness of each of those problems now. The difficulty for them is in trying to embody this fresh orientation in their policies.

I was very glad to see the Assistant Treasurer saying that the bank is aiming to incorporate such cross-cutting concerns as poverty, population, women in development, social sector investment and the environment within its policies. All of those are areas which, in the past, it has not given enough attention to. Now that it is saying it is trying to do that, we should support it in making that a reality. It is encouraging that it says that is its aim.

The honourable member for Curtin said that funds were often misallocated in borrowing countries. I have no doubt that there are some examples of that. I have no doubt that some of the programs have not been successful, and the bank itself has said as much. But it is important that evaluation be strengthened and that part of that evaluation be an attempt to learn from experience and to ensure that, in future, lending is more effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens in Australia too.

—The honourable member is quite correct—it does happen in Australia too. But when there is an awareness of that, the essential requirement is not to reduce funds but to aim to increase the quality of the programs, because they are certainly desperately needed.

PARA.TAB: One criticism of the Asian Development Bank which has also received some attention is that it may not have spent enough of its funds in Australia or on Australian consultants. There has been some attempt to increase the awareness of the private sector in Australia of the opportunities which the bank offers, and it is important that more attention be given to that. When the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade did a report on the World Bank and the IMF, it drew attention to the opportunities which are available to our private sector through the development banks. Since then, there have been a number of public seminars, Austrade has made a much greater effort to publicise those opportunities, and the private sector is more aware now. But more could be done.

The member for Curtin also criticised some countries for their excessive expenditure on military activity and in that I strongly support what he said. There is no doubt that some countries in our region are spending far more than appears to be warranted in strategic terms and that expenditure is absolute waste. It is a tragedy that India, with an enormous poverty problem, is still increasing its military expenditure. It is wasteful. It undermines our confidence that aid funds are going to be well used and it undermines international confidence that that country really knows what it is doing. It is very important that India recognises the damage it does to itself by that kind of activity.

I would like to say a little about the international financial markets. The Asian Development Bank and the other development banks have only a relatively limited brief, that is to channel funds largely from the private sector into development activities. At the same time as the Asian Development Bank has been doing its work, global financial interdependence has grown very strongly. There is now what one would have to recognise as a global international financial market. The problem is that there is great instability in that market, both in terms of the flow of funds and in exchange rates. There needs to be attention given by the development banks—including the IMF because it has become, in effect, an international development bank—to ways of increasing orderliness in international financial markets and to coping with market failure. The most recent example of that market failure was in the collapse of the Mexican peso and the implications that has had for lots of developing countries, including those in our region, which have been borrowing on international financial markets.

There needs to be serious thought given to ways of reducing that international financial instability which can so damage economic and social development within developing countries. There is a risk—one hopes a remote and small risk, but nevertheless a risk—of, at some point, a serious financial collapse in one country leading to similar events in other countries. There was a fear of that for a while in January following the collapse of the Mexican peso.

One possibility for addressing that issue would be for there to be a small tax on international financial transactions imposed globally. That idea is now beginning to get some quite serious consideration. It would have to be part of a package of measures. I read a very interesting article recently by Felix Rohatyn, a major New York financier, who was proposing an international financial organisation equivalent to the World Trade Organisation which would set standards for the international financial markets—accounting standards, reporting standards and provision of information standards. Those standards would make markets more transparent, more predictable and therefore less risky. That is an important part of the reform but another part of the reform is also to reduce the extent of very short-term speculation on international financial markets and that is the problem that this proposal for a small levy would address. It would reduce the incentive for very short-term capital movements and, therefore, would tend to reduce the instability of exchange rates. In so doing it would increase stability of financial markets, reduce the problem of monetary management for governments, raise revenue and be of assistance to governments in a number of ways.

It is a possibility that needs to be seriously studied. It would not be possible to endorse it as an idea yet, because not enough is known about it, but the world summit for social development has suggested that the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations examine that possibility. That idea is something that I endorse. I strongly endorse this bill and am glad that the opposition and the government are so strongly supporting the ADB.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of brief comments to make in relation to what the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), was talking about before I talk specifically about the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: First of all, in terms of the overseas aid question and the size of the amount that goes in overseas aid as a percentage of the budget, I have to say that I would be at one with him in wishing to see that increased. One of the things that he might have regretted in the last decade is that his own government, which has been very vocal on this subject, has not really delivered on a lot of its rhetoric.

I am also pleased to see that government members—not only the honourable member for Fraser, but also the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear)—acknowledged that there are some difficulties with the Asian Development Bank and some of its activities. That is a welcome change from some of the rhetoric we have had from some members on the government side in the last two or three years when this matter has come up where the obvious and the inevitable has been denied.

Perhaps it would be useful just to refresh our memories on some of the matters in this bill that we are being asked to agree to. We are told that the purpose is to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to enter into an agreement with the Asian Development Bank for the provision of additional capital and to issue promissory notes to cover obligations relating to additional callable shares.

We all know, by way of background, that the ADB has 53 member countries, of which 37 are regional members. These include Australia, Japan, the United States, Canada, Germany, China and many other Asian and Pacific countries. Of the members, 33 were classified as developing countries in 1993. The ADB provides loans, policy advice, equity finance and technical support to developing members in our region and large sums of money are lent—we are talking about billions of dollars. Without going through a category of all the individual figures, we are talking about significant amounts of money.

The largest recipients have been China, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Indonesia. Most loans are to finance projects and 78 per cent of them in 1993 were directed to publicly owned or guaranteed projects. ADB lending without a government guarantee totalled some $241 million in 1993. There are two types of loans. We can go into all that technicality but I do not want to repeat what has already been said in that respect. There are some areas such as China and India which, because of their size and because of their access to other forms of financing, are not eligible but, quite clearly, there are large dollops of money that go out from this source to those particular countries.

This aid is not tied, as other forms of aid quite frequently are. Equally, there is no sourcing as to where it comes from. As I understand it, during the 1989-93 period Australia's procurement from ADB projects exceeded contributions by roughly $170 million. So Australian businesses have actually got back more than the country has put in. But perhaps one has also got to look at whether other forms of activity might not have been even more beneficial. As the previous speaker mentioned, quite rightly, Austrade has been promoting this activity much more significantly in recent years, and that has been to the benefit of this country and firms in this country.

During 1993, ADB considered its fourth capital increase to enable an expansion of its operations and identified a number of areas where additional assistance should be provided. These include additional efforts to address poverty through social sector expenditure on items such as health, education and nutrition; population and family planning programs; the integration of environmental matters into ADB considerations; financial sector and capital market reforms; and loans to members who were not previously active borrowers—for example, Cambodia and Vietnam. Following those considerations, it was agreed that the capital of the ADB needed to be doubled and the opportunity was there for member nations to take up that increase. This bill is all about Australia taking up its entitlement to that increased capital.

Perhaps it would be worthwhile spending a few minutes talking about the need for investment in Asia, from this particular source or from other sources, and also the need for aid. The reality is that there are literally billions of poor people in the world, and Asia has more than its fair share.

In addition, rapidly growing economies, better communications and education are raising the expectations of many of our Asian neighbours that they too could share in the good life. These countries need to be assisted as they take the step from being third world countries to, hopefully, first world countries in fairly short order.
We also need to bear in mind that Asia seems to have more than its share of natural disasters. One thinks, particularly, of places such as Bangladesh where every couple of years

SPEECH.PARA: we seem to see television pictures of floods that have occurred there, the hundreds and thousands of people being made homeless, and the many tens of thousands who have been killed. The countries involved really do not have the financial resources to overcome those sorts of crises.

PARA.TAB: There are major food problems in the Asian area, especially in countries with rapidly growing populations such as India and China. But even so-called smaller countries in Asia have significant populations, whether it is Indonesia with 180-odd million, Pakistan with 100-odd million, or much smaller countries such as Thailand with a mere 45-odd million. When one compares their size with Australia's those countries have very significant basic food requirements. In many of those countries the rice yield, for example, is declining. So there is a need for food, services and infrastructure, all of which require money.

I had the good fortune recently to visit Indonesia. It is quite apparent there that there is a dramatic shortage of skills and capital. As a major developing country, our nearest largest neighbour, Indonesia, needs help to develop in the way that we would all wish to see it develop. There is a large category of people in the very poor and starving categories. There is a small upper class and a burgeoning middle class, but that middle class is still surprisingly small. By one estimate that number might be 25 million by 2010 but at the moment it is certainly a very small category.

One of the things that I would like to see ADB and other aid organisations giving more attention to, and the sort of thing that distressed me while I was there, was the direction in which some of the funds are going. In some of the suburbs of northern Jakarta there were people living in absolute, abject poverty; the health was appalling and the education was almost non-existent. The next day I was taken to Bandung up in the mountains where the government is spending literally billions of dollars trying to crash through with a modern aircraft building industry. It is an attempt by a particular government minister to jerk Indonesia out of the backwoods stage into the modern technological era. However, to do that, skills and knowledge are required, and people were actually making planes that I believe will be very hard to sell. In fact, the only ones they are getting rid of are those that are bartered for Malaysian rubber or for someone else's goods in some other part of the world. They are not actually selling any, and the skills that they are having to use are not Indonesian skills; they are having to bring in higher paid American and other overseas aircraft engineers and designers. They have spent millions of dollars on buying the latest technology, which has been left idle on the aircraft factory floor for 90 per cent of the time.

The project is obviously not working successfully, andbillions of dollars are going into this particular project while people are starving in the streets of the capital. As I understand it, some of the health budget was being appropriated to try to top up the funding for the aircraft project when I was there late last year. So I think we have to look very critically at where our aid goes because it seems to me that some of the countries that are major recipients are not necessarily spending that money wisely.

A couple of years ago I was a member of the first Australian parliamentary delegation to go to Pakistan. Pakistan has got a population of about 100 million and the climate is pretty challenging. A fact of life about Pakistan is that it could not survive without outside help. Sixty-seven per cent of the population do not even go to primary school. Only four per cent of the country's forests are left. The natural resources are not there. There is tremendous poverty. The country suffers from environmental degradation and there are incredible education problems. It needs help.

But, again, one has got to look at how that help is directed, because Pakistan spends a huge amount of its national budget on defence. One of the earlier speakers, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), talked about India. There is no doubt that India and Pakistan have a problem over Kashmir and other things. They are both spending quite ridiculous amounts on defence, trying to develop nuclear capabilities, when there are millions in their own countries who need basic housing, health and educational facilities.

I have a concern that much of our aid, however it goes out of this country, is not hitting the target. I interjected briefly, when one of the earlier speakers, the honourable member for Fraser, talked about the fact that there were projects which could be better managed, or do not do what they are aiming to do. I interjected that the same applies in this country, and that is so true, probably nowhere more specifically than with many of our Aboriginal projects, where we are not hitting the target when we should be.

All of those countries that I have talked about—whether Indonesia, Pakistan or Bangladesh—are massive compared with us in population, but certainly not in terms of their economies. We do have some obligation to help those countries. There is the issue of human rights, as was gone into at some length by the honourable gentleman from Curtin. Giving our aid through a third party is a very convenient cover for the government not to have to face up to the question of whether we help countries that have human rights records that we disapprove of. It seems to me that this is a cop-out. Having established that there is a need in many of these countries, but that the aid that is going there is not always being applied as it should, why should there be Australian involvement? Those present will probably infer from what I have said that I believe that, as we are a wealthy country and those countries are far from wealthy, we certainly need to give humanitarian aid.

We need to give aid as a good regional neighbour. For some years we have been saying that we are part of the Asia-Pacific region. We are not an Asian country, but we are located in the area, our future is very much tied up in that area, and we need to do the good neighbourly thing from time to time. At the moment, we get more back than we put in, in terms of the revenue to our companies, but the growth in the area will give much better opportunities for Australian companies in the future.

There are advantages of scale in giving aid through a third party, rather than necessarily tying it directly. As the honourable member for Fraser said, there is no question that for some of those projects the ADB is able to go out and generate more cash at cheaper interest rates. The reality is that the sheer scale of some of those projects means that we would not be able to fund them on a direct basis.

There are some reservations—many of them were well documented by the honourable member for Curtin. The problems of administration, and other difficulties that have been associated with the ADB, are well-known. Whilst there have obviously been some moves to address some of those issues, I am not convinced that they are being pursued with the vigour that is appropriate.

Then we come to the question of whether bilateral aid would in fact do a better job. At least it would be more visible, so we would get the kudos and the credit. It would perhaps help our relationships with those countries which might at present perceive us as a geographically big and economically rich near neighbour which does not appear to be doing too much for them. If we were not paying the money through ADB, we could do it directly and we could get that kudos and benefit.

Certainly I think there are attractions about funding non-government organisations. On some of my trips in the last couple of years I have seen that some of the best work being done has undoubtedly been done through the non-government agencies. I have seen work with non-government agencies as well as government agencies in Indonesia and in Thailand, for example, and I believe there is no doubt that those NGOs give us more bang for our buck. I think that is something to be applauded. It seems to me that on bilateral aid we get the same sorts of benefits and probably fewer problems.

It concerns me that we really do not have too much control about where the money that is channelled through ADB actually finishes up, so generally I would prefer to see bilateral aid. It seems to me that we get more value for our dollar, and it is therefore in the interests of both countries; but I recognise the need for some third party funding.

In conclusion, I believe that overall there are good reasons for being involved in the ADB, but I think we need to monitor its performance on an ongoing basis—and probably with more rigour than we have done hitherto. Australia has been committed to this exercise from the very start, and is a major player. It is appropriate that we should therefore take up the opportunity to increase our shareholding at this stage. As has been said previously, the coalition supports the bill in spite of its reservations; but were we in government we would want to look at the whole subject in a lot more detail and a with lot more substance, to make sure there are not better ways of helping those in the world who are less fortunate than ourselves. It is in our interests, as well as their interests, to see their lot improved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I stand today to support the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994, a bill that I note has the support of both sides of the House. The issue that it raises is important in terms of our position in the region and our activities within the region, and all sides agree that the government should be involved in it to further Australia's interests and the interests of the Asia-Pacific region.

PARA.TAB: The bill relates to a decision by the board of governors of the Asian Development Bank which increased the bank's authorised capital stock by 1,770,497 shares and authorised the acceptance of increases in individual members' subscriptions. The capital increase is one in which each member may subscribe to additional shares equal to its present subscription. Therefore, if all members subscribe fully, the capital of the bank will be doubled and the relative shareholdings of members will remain unaltered. This bill empowers the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to make the necessary agreement with the Asian Development Bank for the purchase by Australia of its entitlement of 2,047 additional paid-in shares and 100,323 additional callable shares of the capital stock of the bank.

Australia's involvement in the issue of foreign aid is something that previous speakers have dwelled upon, and it is also one that I would like to speak about briefly today. Like the previous speakers, the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) and the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore)—and, no doubt, others—I am concerned about the level of foreign aid that the government is providing. I do not believe that we are doing as much as we should be in that area, and certainly within the government I have been one who has endeavoured to urge movement on the level of foreign aid.

Our involvement in the Asian Development Bank is a form of foreign aid and, as has also been said by others, it is a cost-effective form of foreign aid. Through the processes of the bank, and through the fact that our capacity to contribute is there with the capacity of others, it provides a larger pool for investment purposes and therefore ensures more value for money with respect to its actual impact.

In terms of what the role of the bank and foreign aid do for Australia, we have often talked in this place and in other places about the question of the need for the development of a greater regionalisation and internationalisation of the economy. Although many of us have concerns about how that has actually panned out, I think everyone agrees that there is a need for greater regionalisation of economic development in this area and that Australia has to play a key role in development within the region. As I have said, this is one way to do it, an effective way to do it and a way that should be encouraged. The benefits for Australia flow on from that. As the investments from the bank lead to improved trade and financial flows, they also lead to enhanced living standards from the resultant economic growth.
Australia participates actively in the work done by the projects. I have figures here from the bank's annual report:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1993, Australia's direct procurement with the ADB amounted to $108 million or 2.6 per cent of the total. During the five years 1989-93, Australia's procurement amounted to $432 million.

These are again major figures in terms of export benefits for Australian firms involved in the operations of the bank. When we are in a situation of assisting development within the region, an area where there are extremely high levels of poverty, starvation, disease and other difficulties, there is a capacity to assist in the development of regional stability.

PARA.TAB: There is a benefit through the processes of the Asian Development Bank in terms of regional security. Also, there is the question of our overall moral responsibility in alleviating poverty. The honourable member for Fraser mentioned that large parts of Asia are in a situation akin to Dickensian England with regard to the level of abject poverty and the desperation of the plight of the people who live there. That is also causing significant environmental dangers with respect to the sort of development that can occur and is occurring in parts of Asia. There are also questions of human rights. I do not pretend for one minute that the bank in itself is going to resolve all of these matters, but through its publications and through the investments that it makes it is assisting in addressing concerns on many of these issues, trying to lead Asia through to a more developed and, hopefully, environmentally friendly development approach for the future.

Earlier speakers have alluded to problems with the bank as they have been perceived over time. There have been a number of problems. The bank's administrative efficiency has been the object of some debate over the years. There are signs of improvement in that area. The questions of first-class air fares and the Rolls Royce approach of the bank have been addressed. Certainly Australia has been at the forefront of raising those concerns within the bank.

A question which is often raised about foreign aid is whether projects that are undertaken give value for money and whether they actually work. That is an issue of some debate. There are always examples of foreign aid not being successful in its objectives but there are also excellent examples of where it has been successful. The bank conducts post-evaluation processes for its projects and programs, and has provided an amount of useful data on that question. It uses this data in the formulation, design and implementation of new projects. The post-evaluation carried out in 1993 covered 26 projects, of which 16 projects were classified as generally successful, six projects as partly successful and four projects as unsuccessful, those being about 15 per cent of the activities in that time.

Through those post-evaluation processes the bank has also identified the need to improve its performance in a range of areas. These include the need to provide greater assistance to borrowing countries in order to improve their administrative and institutional compatibilities in handling economic development tasks, to improve analysis of risks and uncertainties associated with bank projects, to incorporate measures of benefit monitoring and evaluation in the design of projects, and also to provide greater attention to maintenance requirements of projects once they are completed.

To many of us, all those things seem to be commonsense, but the bank is not the only organisation to make those types of errors. These processes and objectives must be continually maintained in the future to ensure that we get value for money and that the economy is assisted, through the work of the bank, to get value for money.

The bank carried out an overall evaluation of approximately 425 projects up to the end of 1993, and this evaluation goes beyond the earlier evaluation which I spoke about. The view of the bank is that 60 per cent were generally successful, 29 per cent were partly successful and only 11 per cent were unsuccessful. As a scorecard regarding success, that is not a bad position to be in with the very difficult issues of trying to encourage and to make successful development projects in economies and areas that are, by definition, often the most difficult parts of the countries involved.

With respect to Australia and the ADB, there are some issues raised in an article in the publication Australia and ADB: A Fact Sheet, which details some of the aspects regarding Australia's involvement in the area. Australia is the fifth largest shareholder in the ADB. The ADB has a range of activities and there are various types of loans, grants, share schemes, et cetera involved. The ADB arranges co-financing from bilateral, multilateral and commercial sources as additional resources of the project financing. Co-financing in 1993 amounted to about $US3.5 billion for 24 loans and $US90 million for technical assistance grants. Cumulatively, ADB's co-financing amounted to $US18.6 billion for 398 loans and $US204 million for 297 technical assistance grants as of the end of September 1994.

Australia's involvement with this cumulative co-financing was 14 loans and three technical assistance grants, totalling $US38.3 million. In terms of bilateral loans, there were 11 loans, amounting to $US30.6 million. Those loans were co-financed for projects in countries such as the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, the Republic of Korea, Malaysia, Nepal, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Tonga and Western Samoa. That information will give you a broad idea of the fact that the aid being provided through the bank and through Australia is being used throughout the region to provide worthwhile projects to areas which are in desperate need.

I alluded earlier to the involvement of Australian companies in projects through the ADB, and the question of the projects providing a direct benefit to Australia in terms of export earnings. That question is worth looking at here today. With respect to Australia's involvement in that area, its share from January to September 1994 was $US30.4 million. In 1993 it was $US77.4 million, and there was a cumulative basis through to September 1994 of approximately $US554.4 million. It can be seen that we are talking about relatively large sums of money which have come back to Australia. As the honourable member for Aston mentioned, the figures show that Australian exports earned through this process actually exceed Australian investment within the bank. It is, therefore, a value for money investment for Australia in humanitarian terms, in regional terms and in terms of the firms which are involved.

There is a range of contractors who are involved in this process: John Lysaght Ltd, just outside my electorate in Melbourne; L.M. Ericcson Pty Ltd, also in Melbourne, just outside my electorate on the other side; Hawker Noyes Pty Ltd; and Princess Shipping Ltd. The list goes on.

Consulting firms are also actively involved in the processes of the ADB, and they have carried out significant work on behalf of the ADB in terms of the projects that they have undertaken. Some examples are: BHP Engineering; the Hawthorn Institute of Education; Stephenson and Turner; Gibb Australia; and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. We can see that, all the way through, there have been significant Australian firms involved in the development of ADB proposals and in construction in the countries which require it.

When carrying out research for this speech, I looked at the ADB Review, which is a publication of the Asian Development Bank, published on a two-monthly basis. That publication is worth looking at in terms of seeing the wide range of activities that the ADB is involved in. I am very impressed with the level of information in the ADB Review, not only in terms of balance sheets and with respect to what investments are occurring where, but also with the articles which detail the impact of the projects that the ADB is carrying out, and the great need for those projects to occur across a range of countries.

I think it is very important to look at these publications in terms of this issue, and I would encourage anyone interested in the issue of foreign aid to look at the ADB Review, because it really does highlight the compassionate and the humanitarian aspects of foreign aid, and it puts faces and names to the debate, which I think is important in terms of recognising the real effect that these activities actually have in terms of people's living standards.

In the September-October 1994 issue of ADB Review, there is an article on Bangladesh titled `Urban poverty: how bad is it?' A survey of 21 secondary towns in Bangladesh was undertaken to look at this issue and it came up with some very disturbing figures on what is happening in that country. The article read:

SPEECH.PARA: The survey showed that 39 per cent of all sampled households fell below the poverty line. Roughly one third of the poor were hard core, living on the borderline of starvation. In the slum areas, nearly half the population were hard core poor. Fifty per cent of the adult urban poor were found to be illiterate. The rate was 61 per cent in the slum areas.

That article goes on to look at not only the question of the problems faced in Bangladesh on this issue, but also what the bank is endeavouring to do through its loan processes and through work with the government of Bangladesh and in conjunction with other governments to actually remedy some of those problems. It is an enormous task to try and achieve. Again I quote:
Since January 1989 it—
the bank—

has provided Bangladesh with four loans totalling $213.7 million for the development of urban infrastructure. This makes the bank the largest among the donors to this sector, which include the World Bank, the United Nations Children's Fund and the governments of Japan and the Netherlands.

The infrastructure projects are involved with things like flood protection, water supply and sanitation. As we are all aware from watching the TV news, we often see at night pictures of natural disasters. I have noticed that they seem to be more and more often in the Asian area and they often relate to floods or typhoons. Certainly the danger of disease in those areas is very severe. It often relates to the question of sanitation. In this case there are projects which directly address those concerns.

PARA.TAB: There has been a study in Asia on the impact of AIDS and the need to address that issue. There are also details on the question of population growth in that area, which I think is an issue which has also been a matter of some public debate in Australia. There are some very interesting statistics on the question of the population challenge we face across the world, but particularly in Asia. Three babies are born in the world every second, and two of those are actually in Asia. That means the growth in Asia's population each day is somewhere in the region of 150,000 people.

It is an extremely large problem in terms of the difficulties that produces for governments and for communities in dealing with that increased population, and that creates enormous pressures on infrastructure services within countries. Can we imagine the situation if Melbourne or Sydney was growing at that rate in a situation where we did not have the infrastructure services already there? It would be a major national problem and something that would need to be addressed—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of people moving to Queensland.

—Certainly many are, after the Kennett government's arrival in Victoria. It is a very pleasant place to go to, I must admit. I have visited there, and I know the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) is an active advocate on behalf of the glories of Queensland—
—And the Sunshine Coast.
—And the Sunshine Coast in particular. I note that the member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) is attempting to do something along those lines. I wish him all the very best.

PARA.TAB: Lack of family planning and maternal health care are a real problem in those areas, and I think these also relate to very important issues for women in those areas. As in any society, the major activities in terms of raising families fall to women. In situations where there are virtually no support services and a real lack of health and educational services, the difficulties are just phenomenal.

The bank itself has supported Indonesia's development goals. Particularly in terms of Indonesia, we are looking at a situation where there has been a major effort to try to have public education programs to assist people to understand the issue of family planning, the need to be careful about the question of how many kids you can afford, and how you can, in a way, successfully manage your family. That program has been quite successful and over a billion dollars has gone from the bank into projects in that area. That, in itself, is crucial. I again quote the Director of ADB's Infrastructure Department, on this issue. Sayed Baha says:

SPEECH.PARA: Investing in women's education will result in high social gains and economic benefits. A better educated mother raises a healthier family and will have fewer but better educated children. Education provides women with greater employment opportunities and more income. These economic gains will motivate families to have less children, build demand for family planning services and lead to fertility decline.

I am not one who would endorse the draconian measures that have been used, as I understand it, in the PRC for population control, but I do think it is very important to have a situation where the people in these countries have the information to make their own choice about what they do with respect to their families. I also note from the publication that the major cause of death for women of child-bearing years is childbirth itself. It is an absolute tragedy that, in the very act of giving birth and giving life, so many should die. That childbirth is the major cause of death is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: The issue of the environment, which I also mentioned earlier, is a major concern in terms of Asia. The fact is that in many respects the scope for rampant development and the lack of existing industries put Asian economies under enormous pressure to develop at almost any cost. I was very concerned to see in a recent study that Asia was predicted to become the largest future source in the world of greenhouse gas emissions. If unchecked, such emissions will warm up the climate enough to increase typhoons and cyclones and raise sea levels, thus causing increased flooding, erosion, damage to crops and, following on from that, starvation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they going to have a carbon tax, too?
—Who knows? What I would say to you is that this is an important issue and I support it and commend it to the house.

—I am very pleased to have the opportunity to join in this debate on behalf of the coalition. As has been indicated by prior coalition speakers, we are not opposing the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994. Indeed, the former shadow minister for foreign affairs, the Hon. Andrew Peacock, last year expressed support for Australia to take up the additional share capital in the Asian Development Bank, which indeed is authorised by the bill currently before the Main Committee.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the bill is in effect to make it possible for us to take out the additional subscription in capital to the Asian Development Bank, which was set up in 1966 to assist development programs and to assist in improving the standard of living in many countries of the Asia-Pacific. At the present time, there are 53 members. Some of those are, of course, countries in the region, and others are countries outside the region. Australia has always been a major player in the Asian Development Bank. Indeed, as far as we are concerned, the Asian Development Bank has been a major institution in our multilateral development program.

The ADB provides loans, policy advice, equity finance and technical assistance to developing member countries of the Asia-Pacific region. Government spokesmen often say that Australia is part of Asia. I recently was part of a parliamentary delegation which had a bilateral visit to Singapore and Indonesia and also to the Philippines to attend the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference. It was really brought home to me during that visit how much Australia is part of the Asia-Pacific region and how we must learn to operate in our part of the world.

It was, however, interesting to hear the comments made by a number of the parliamentarians from other countries, who thought that it was ridiculous for Australians to say that they are part of Asia. We are obviously not part of Asia, but of course we ought never to forget that we live in the Asia-Pacific region. To be credible in those countries, one must make credible statements and, when some of our government spokesmen say that Australia is an Asian nation, people from overseas just about fall off their chairs laughing.

However, it is important that Australia plays a role in the Asia-Pacific region. I have always known just how important that part of the world is to Australia. However, when I went to Asia and saw the development, the progress, the shared goals and common interests that we have with those countries, it brought home to me in a clear, compelling and concise way just how important that part of the world is to us. Thus I am very pleased that politicians on both sides of politics have taken a bipartisan approach to the Asia-Pacific region and to the importance that the Asia-Pacific region will play in the future of this country.

The capital currently available from the Asian Development Bank is of two kinds: pay-in capital and callable capital. The increase in capital involves the actual payment by members of the paid-in component and the potential liability for the callable component. The callable component of the bank's capital serves as collateral against which the bank borrows funds for on-lending. Fortunately, because the bank has been fairly well run over the years, the bank's loans have been financed largely by funds borrowed from international financial markets.

Most importantly from Australia's point of view—and, indeed, I imagine, from the point of view of the other investing countries—a call on the callable capital of the bank has never been made. This is because the bank's prudent financial policies and healthy level of reserves has meant that that has not happened in the past and it is unlikely to occur in the future.

However, when we look at what this particular legislation is going to cost the country, we ought to look not only at what we must pay in the six annual instalments, but also at our potential liability. If there were some kind of international monetary catastrophe, Australia could well be called upon to pay out the full amount of its liability. It is very bad economics, where a certain amount of money has to be paid now and the rest does not have to be paid for quite some time, and maybe never, to disregard what could be the ultimate liability.

I am interested in the fact that this is part of Australia's multilateral aid program. In the Australian community we have various competing strands of thought in relation to foreign aid. In a robust democracy such as Australia's, one would have to applaud the fact that we have differing views and we have contesting and competing ideas. I am sure that many people contact the electoral office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) and indeed all of our electoral offices and suggest that charity should begin at home and that, while many people in this country are in a state of poverty, Australia ought not to be shovelling money out the door to assist overseas countries.

On the other hand, Australians have a conscience and there are very many people who believe that Australia's international aid effort, up to the present time, may not have been adequate. I suppose that people on both sides of politics must try to straddle those two competing views.

I was very pleased to read that Australia receives more benefit from its contributions than it pays out. I was concerned to see that the ADB loans are not tied and the recipients are not required to spend the aid in the country that provided it. We have all heard horrendous stories of how a nation gives a cash donation, for example, to buy tractors, and because the tractors produced by the donating nation are too expensive, the receiving nation then uses those dollars to shop around and get cheaper tractors. Thus I have always taken the view that, wherever possible, Australian aid ought to be in kind. For instance, if we are giving aid for food then we should send Australian wheat or some other Australian produce.

Similarly, those members who represent manufacturing electorates, like the Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, would understand how beneficial it would be to Australian industry if it were possible to include the goods that we have manufactured as part of Australia's aid projects. That way there is a win-win situation: the overseas country receives the aid and the Australian farmers and the Australian workers receive a benefit. We boost the economy of an overseas nation and improve its standard of living at the same time as we create jobs for Australian workers and Australian farmers.

I think that win-win situation ought to be applauded. It ought to be encouraged but I do accept that it is not possible to achieve that on every occasion. One would have expected that because the receiving country is not required to invest the aid received back in the donating country we might have been worse off; but I noticed that during the period from 1989 to 1993 Australia's procurement from ADB exceeded contributions by approximately $170 million.

Major procurements from Australia by ADB cover goods, related services, civil works and consultancy services. I am pleased to see that Austrade helps with the effort to increase Australia's procurement. We have a full-time commissioner in Manila to promote Australian investment in ADB projects. I would hope that, if the situation occurred where the government saw that Australia was receiving less than its contributions, we might perhaps seek to change the rules to the extent that we tie our aid in a greater way.

There are some overseas nations which do a much better job than Australia in seeking reciprocal benefit for aid given. Japan is one country which immediately comes to mind. Recently, as part of a parliamentary delegation, we visited a number of AIDAB projects in East Timor and also in the Philippines. I was pleased to see the reciprocal benefit that Australia is getting but I wonder whether we are doing enough in that area. We could always hose down those people who say that charity should begin at home if we could prove, and continue to prove in a very clear way, that there is benefit to Australia by giving overseas aid. We might even be able to provide more aid if we have an increased inflow of benefit to the Australian economy as a result of that particular aid.

This bill is quite a short bill; it is only a page or two. The opposition does not oppose the bill. If we did oppose it, we would not be debating it this morning in the Main Committee. The bill specifically empowers the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to make the necessary agreement with the Asian Development Bank for the purchase by Australia of its entitlement of 2,047 additional paid-in shares and 100,323 additional callable shares of the capital stock of the bank. Australia currently holds 102,370 shares in the bank. Those shares are valued at $1.406 billion. That represents just over six per cent of the total capital subscribed in the bank.

Of this figure, the amount that has already been paid to the bank is $168.8 million and the remaining $1.237 billion is subject to call. As I said before, as yet there has not been a call made on those balance funds and hopefully there will not be a call; but the government must always budget for the possibility that such a call could be made. The fact that Australia, a medium sized country, has six per cent of the capital of the Asian Development Bank indicates in a very clear way and sends a message to the world that Australia is shouldering its share of responsibility for boosting the living standards of people in the Asia-Pacific region. We are the fourth largest regional shareholder in the ADB and the fifth largest overall. Australia is a founding member of the bank.

The opposition joins with the government in supporting the bill currently before the committee. The opposition does, indeed, have no concerns over the fact that Australia is increasing its capital in the bank.
